list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The diagram below shows a tennis ball of mass $m$ striking a wall with an initial velocity, $u$, and rebounding with velocity $v$. A second, softer ball of the same mass strikes the wall with the same speed but rebounds with a slower rebound speed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bbeffe1-fadb-4f69-a8f6-5a1deb1f20d3/images/a440cac5-43c9-4b14-97ec-4b768f633978/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.33.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following statements is correct about the magnitudes of the impulse and change in momentum applied to the second ball compared to the first?

$\hspace{1em}$  Impulse$\hspace{1em}$Change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterSmaller$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerSmaller
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in momentum and impulse applied to the ball are equal, because the impulse is defined as the change in momentum. Increasing one is the same as increasing the other and vice-versa. The slower rebound speed of the second ball causes a decrease in the magnitude of the impulse since the change in momentum is smaller if the final speed $v$ is smaller.


- $J = \Delta p = m(v - -u) = m(v + u)$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
An object of mass $M$ on a string moves in a circle of radius $r$ at a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6590a45d-55a7-400f-b7b5-4f31b825e7ad/images/ab24556d-04d2-418a-b7f4-9e1ca037a3f1/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.28.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)



Below are three statements about the motion of the object:


- I. $\hspace{1.1em}$ The resultant work done on the object is zero.
- II. $\hspace{0.8em}$ The velocity of the object is constant.
- III. $\hspace{0.5em}$ The object is accelerating

Which of the statements is/are true?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I is correct. 
The accelerating force is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, therefore no work is done.


- $W = Fs \cos\theta$, and $\theta$ is always 90$\degree$, and $\cos 90 \degree =0$

Also, $W=\Delta E_k$ and the speed of the object is constant so there is no change in kinetic energy.
II is incorrect. 
Because velocity is a vector quantity and the direction is constantly changing, velocity is not constant.
III is correct. 
Because velocity is constantly changing, the object is always accelerating.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
An object moves in a circular path of radius $2$ m with angular displacement of $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ rad in $5$ s.
What is the average linear speed of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{20}$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{10}$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The linear speed is given by


- $v=r\omega$

and


- $\omega=\dfrac{\Delta \theta }{\Delta t}$

Then:


- $v = (r) \dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t} = (2) \dfrac{(\frac{\pi}{2})}{5} = \dfrac{\pi}{5}$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
A skydiver of weight, $W$, of a skydiver falls through air with a drag force $F_{drag}$
If the skydiver experiences terminal velocity, which of the following best represents the free body diagram of the skydiver?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/f7d98c67-c67c-413e-b6dc-6ce1eaddd8f0/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.28%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/7e66ac3f-29ca-49cc-965b-4b1ac077eb37/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/c264232f-f4f5-4f65-b6d4-07507de5161f/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c5e968b4-d927-490b-9df8-95e8e1c4c510/images/26ffa821-04f6-4987-8f19-ab4c4a016b76/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.26.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At terminal velocity there is no accleration. Forces must be balanced, therefore the drag force is equal and opposite to the weight.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A car of mass $m$ and a truck of mass $3m$ travelling in opposite directions collide and stick together. The speeds of the car and the truck just before the crash are $2v$ and $v$ respectively. What is their speed after the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{1}{4}v$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{4}{5}v$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5}{4}v$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	4v $
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The vehicles move in opposite directions, therefore the total momentum before the collision is


- $m(2v)+(-3m)v=-mv$

By the principle of conservation of momentum, the momentum of the vehicles after the collision is equal to the total momentum before the collision.


- $-mv=\left(m+3m\right)v_f$

where $v_f$ is the velocity of the vehicles after the collisions.


- $v_f=\dfrac{-mv}{4m}$
- $v_f=\dfrac{-v}{4}$

Therefore the speed is $\dfrac{1}{4}v$.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The diagram below shows an object attached to a light inextensible string. The object is travelling in a horizontal circle at a constant speed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1407380-c5d8-4cf6-8000-1ed0057396fd/images/86154aae-6a39-4d62-927f-7719e616b6c7/image.png)


What is the direction of the resultant force acting on the object? Select from the labeled arrows on the diagram.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The object is moving in a circle at a constant speed so the resultant force = centripetal force. The centripetal force is directed towards the center of the circular path that the object is following. The answer is D.
There are two forces acting on the object. Weight (acting in the direction C) and tension (acting in direction A). The resultant of these two forces in the vertical plane is zero. The resultant force is the horizontal component of the tension (acting in the direction D).

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
A mass is attached to the mirror of a car by a string. As the car accelerates to the left, the string makes an angle with the vertical as shown in the diagram below.

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ee790bc8-4dcf-4256-a8a8-461ce679380c/images/602e6fb6-06ca-4100-8bca-5ed867a031af/PH0284A.png)

B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ee790bc8-4dcf-4256-a8a8-461ce679380c/images/431a6c61-ce3f-4bf0-bc82-a9ea69f3f37a/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.36.52%E2%80%AFPM.png)

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The graph below shows the variation of the resultant force $F$ acting on a box with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9dfa696e-4fd4-4a7a-90d1-8830c669456a/PH0579q.png)


The box starts to move from rest. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the momentum $p$ of the box with time $t$?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/71fb8624-3e7f-4803-b78f-8670d2c4c075/PH0579a.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/5df1dc95-d879-42fa-9bf5-f4a182c14b3f/PH0579b.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/10ae312c-2976-4a62-98e5-18a7efeb0dc4/PH0579c.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9fb48b7f-abee-43b9-9d28-76767fb4650b/PH0579d.png)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The area underneath of the force-time graph gives the change in momentum of the box. Since the area increases with time at a constant rate, the momentum should increase at a constant rate. The only graph that satisfies this condition is the graph in A.
Therefore, the answer is A.
Alternatively, the impulse equation gives $\Delta p = F \Delta t$ .
As $F$ is a constant,  $\Delta p$ is directly proportional to $t$ and a straight line through the origin is expected.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
As a truck is brought to rest, the brakes apply a force of $5.1 \times 10^3$ N. Which answer best describes the magnitude of the change in momentum of the truck if the brakes are applied for 3.0 s?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $15$ kN s
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $15000$ N s
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $15.3$ kN s
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $15300$ N s
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
NOTE this question requires students to use their judgement to determine the best answer, using standard scientific conventions.


- Impulse = change in momentum =
$F \,t $

So the magnitude of the change in momentum:


- $\Delta p= (5.1 \times 10^3$)(3.0) = 15300 N s

All responses match this quantity but the number of significant figures needs to be considered. As both of the values used in the calculation have two significant figures, there should be two significant figures in the answer.
In the answer $15000$ N s, the number of significant figures is unclear. It could be 2, 3, 4 or 5. The response $15$ kN s clearly has two significant figures, so it is the best answer.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
A football player bounced the ball off their head as shown while diving sideways:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db6d3d8f-a4f9-44a6-ac1d-3d502dc3fe03/images/625404da-8e05-4718-839c-665afe99d9b7/PH0146-1.png)


Which of the following gives a Newton's Third Law pair of forces that applies to this situation?

Force 1Force 2$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the ball on the playerForce of the ball on the earth$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the player on the earthForce of the ball on the player$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the earth on the ballForce of the ball on the earth$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Force of the earth on the playerForce of the player on the ball
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The only combination of answers which mentions the correct Newton’s Third Law  force pair is C. In Newton’s Third Law force pairs always occur between only the same two objects.
In this case, because the ball and Earth are not in contact, it is the gravitational force that is equal and opposite here.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A block of wood is placed on a rough inclined surface. Which of the diagrams below correctly represents the forces acting on the block when it is at rest?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/6fd66c35-5858-47b6-b951-7ef859c5bc49/PH0261A.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/1efb7d4e-b506-4e9a-b16f-c5b29f42f15e/PH0261B.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$ $\hspace{1cm}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/d118c599-94cf-4412-bd58-11ec3f440b08/PH0261C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/371d44f4-7847-4a00-acd9-301f34fdd9b2/PH0261D.png)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Weight always acts vertically downwards
Normal reaction force is always normal (perpendicular) to the surface
In order to remain at rest, friction must act up the incline in order to keep the block from sliding down the incline under the action of the component of weight acting down the incline.
In diagram B, friction is acting down the incline. This will result in an acceleration down the incline.
In diagram C, the normal reaction is acting opposite to the weight whereas normal reaction must always be perpendicular to the contact surface.
In diagram D, weight is shown to act at an angle to the vertical, whereas weight always acts vertically downwards.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A spring of negligible mass and length of $l_o$ is attached to a fixed point. When the spring is extended by an external force $F$, the length of the spring increases to $l$.  The graph shows how the length of the spring $L$ varies with the tension $T$ in the spring. The tension in the spring is equal to $k \Delta l$, where k is a constant and $\Delta l$ is the extension of the spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2bfce454-555d-4156-93d8-281993a72810/images/edd72a10-fd02-4b98-92fe-bdc00c06f9eb/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.57.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


What are the gradient and y-intercept of the graph?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ Gradient $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ y-intercept $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ A. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $l$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $l_o$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $k$ $l_o$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $\Delta l$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The y-intercept is the length of the spring when there is no external force. Therefore, the y-intercept is $l_o$
Gradient is $\cfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$ on the graph
Hooke's Law states that $F = k\Delta x$ and in this case $\Delta x = l - l_o$
The gradient = $\cfrac{l-l_o}{F} = \cfrac{\Delta x}{F}$
Therefore, $gradient = \dfrac{1}{k}$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
A ball of mass $m$ is falling vertically through the air. The drag force acting on the ball is given by $kv^2$ where $k$ is constant and $v$ is the speed of the ball. What is the maximum speed reached by the ball?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{k}{mg}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{mg}{k}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{mg}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
While the ball is falling, two opposite forces act on it. These are weight and drag. The speed of the ball increases until the drag force balances the weight. Therefore, the following expression can be written for maximum speed $v_{max}$:


- $k(v_{max})^2=mg$
- $(v_{max})^2=\dfrac{mg}{k}$
- $v_{max}=\sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}$

Hence, the correct answer is D.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
A ball is projected in an environment where air resistance can be ignored.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55e5a7c7-e06b-43bd-b2a7-937785b48186/images/f5a849d5-4b91-48e8-8544-378baedb4072/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.05.30%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Which graph shows the variation of the resultant force $R$ acting on the ball with the height $h$ of the object?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55e5a7c7-e06b-43bd-b2a7-937785b48186/images/8d90da58-a87f-49e4-8679-95bcee689c8d/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2011.10.29%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55e5a7c7-e06b-43bd-b2a7-937785b48186/images/9be3ad8f-ef3a-4461-86a4-0725f98babbf/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2011.10.57%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55e5a7c7-e06b-43bd-b2a7-937785b48186/images/da77e9a0-aed9-4204-9929-548fd26fbeb3/Screenshot%202025-05-26%20at%2011.11.10%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55e5a7c7-e06b-43bd-b2a7-937785b48186/images/f917928b-dc41-4cb9-946a-286ed3691d55/Screenshott%202025-05-26%20at%2011.11.16%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to the absence of air resistance, the only force acting on the ball is weight and its magnitude is constant. Therefore, the resultant force should be constant during the motion. The only graph that represents this situation is the graph in B.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Two eggs of equal mass fall from the same height onto a padded floor. One of them is broken while the other one bounces upwards intact. The time of collision is the same for both. Which of the following correctly describes the egg that exerts a greater averge force on the floor and the reason?

Egg with greater average forceReason$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$BrokenGreater change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$BouncesLess change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$BrokenLess change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$BouncesGreater change in momentum
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
As the direction of motion of the bouncing egg is changed after the collision, it has a greater change in velocity than the egg that breaks. Therefore, its has a greter change in momentum.
The time of collision is the same for both situations. According to $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}$, the force acting on the egg that bounces back is greater. By using Newton’s third law, it can be stated that the average force acting on the floor from the bouncing egg is greater.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Small marbles with equal mass but different diameters are released in liquids with different densities. Which of the following combinations of marble and the density of the liquid will result in the shortest time for the marble to fall a given height?  Assume that in all cases the marbles sink in the liquid and the viscosity of the liquid is constant.

$\hspace{1.5em}$Diameter of the marble$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$The density of the liquid$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Smaller diameterLower density$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater diameterLower density$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Smaller diameterHigher density$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater diameterHigher density
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
A released marble can cover the same distance in a shorter time when it has greater acceleration. To get greater acceleration, the resultant force downward should be bigger. Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards. Note that because the marbles are stated to have equal masses, the downwards force of gravity on both marbles is the same.
The buoyant force:


- $F_b = V\rho g$

Weight:


- $W=mg$

Drag:


- $F_d = 6\pi \eta rv$

The resultant force $F_{net}$:


- $F_{net}=mg-(V\rho g+6\pi \eta rv)$

Based on the equation above, when the drag force or buoyancy is reduced, the resultant force becomes greater. As the density of the liquid decreases, the magnitude of the buoyant force decreases.
Moreover, a decrease in diameter directly leads to a decrease in drag force and buoyancy.
Alternatively, if we consider the terminal velocity, this results when the net force is zero.
Therefore


- $F_g = F_d+F_b$
- $mg = \rho V g+6\pi \eta rv$

Solving for terminal velocity gives


- $v = \dfrac{mg-\rho V g}{6\pi \eta r}$

Substituting the fomula for the volume of a sphere


- $v = \dfrac{mg-\rho (\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3) g}{6\pi \eta r}$

We see that as $r$ increases, the numerator will at some point reach zero. This will be the point at which the density of the marble equals the density of the fluid. We are told that the marble always sinks, and so the numerator must remain positive.
Looking at the expression, decreasing $r$ will have the effect of both increasing the numerator (thus increasing the velocity) and decreasing the denominator (also increasing the velocity).

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
A jet aircraft is performing a “loop-the-loop” stunt in which it moves in a vertical circular path as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/d0824da3-0194-4631-aa10-9d3ce1dfd00f/PH00631zz.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by nnaakk from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$

Which of the following represents the free body diagram of the pilot at the top of the loop?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/4c742c4f-98f0-4d85-a677-6f1c23762946/PH0631az.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/8067d5fd-b147-485f-a09c-216f201100a5/PH0631bz.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/6feee77a-249b-4a4b-930a-4620c1310f57/PH0631cz.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/90c5b45a-7c54-4da3-a9d9-5ad0b4ad3cac/images/47a89b02-ad42-4196-b582-3b7bc3e63fbb/PH0631dz.png)

$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
There are two forces acting on the pilot which are the gravitational force (weight) and the normal force of the pilot's chair.
The normal force always acts from the chair onto the person. At the top of the loop, this will act vertically downwards.
The weight is always vertically downwards.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
In an explosion, an initially stationary object splits into three fragments that move in two dimensions. Which of the following vector diagrams could $\textbf{not}$ represent the momenta of the fragments just after the explosion?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/3f088da2-196c-409a-8aa4-94eb798cfc04/image.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/60cca5c7-c60a-4e4a-b7e5-ac87290feba1/image.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/f513976c-5908-49ed-96be-2d0e61241548/image.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/4f1bb5d4-67e6-4927-8c06-3094da08d90b/image.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Initially the object is stationary, so momentum is zero. Momentum is conserved so momentum the total momentum of the fragments after the explosion is zero.
If the total momentum is zero, the momentum vectors when added together must form a closed vector triangle / cancel out in all directions.
Looking at the diagram in C, we can see that there is a net vertical component.
A good way to approach this question is to try and visualize - or redraw the vectors connected top to tail. For these vectors that should look like this.
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/9fb59a05-a637-45f0-9c91-a2b8bd4eab12/image.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/902ad810-6937-42ee-9dbb-961a50537c4b/image.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/2e33358e-0516-4e9e-a97c-b991155a9718/image.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aaa227b9-001d-4d7f-b040-4c74ed82be64/images/1c754613-9b38-406d-8179-621325af342a/image.png)

C is the only set of vectors here that does not form a closed triangle.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
A stone attached to one end of a rod rotates in a vertical circle at a constant speed. Two positions of the stone at two different instants, X and Y, are shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d4352f8d-c820-4f4d-bca6-df53ec8d5067/images/791ea751-6d76-46b7-bc0b-d17159b63e87/PH0231-1.png)



In the table below, which row is correct for the centripetal force acting on the stone at X and Y?

$\hspace{1em}$ Direction of centripetal force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$Magnitude of centripetal force$\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$SameSame$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$SameDifferent$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$DifferentSame$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$DifferentDifferent
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The centripetal force on an object undergoing uniform circular motion is always towards the centre of the circle therefore the direction is different at the different locations. The magnitude of centripetal force is dependent on the radius of the circular path and the speed of the object. Since both locations have the same radius and speed, the magnitude of centripetal force is constant throughout the motion. Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The diagram below shows the total upward and downward forces acting on a hot air balloon. The relative magnitudes of the forces are drawn to scale.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df4cb97a-03e0-4bd8-a84c-8dda7444c026/images/3942c2b5-5966-4703-a368-fe8f703caa1a/PH0968Edit.png)


Below are three independent statements about the possible motion of the balloon.


- I.The balloon is acceleratingII.The balloon is moving upwardsIII.The balloon is moving downwards

Which of the statements, when considered independently, could be true?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I is correct - The diagram shows that the upward force is greater than the downward force. So, there is a net upward force acting on the balloon. $F=ma$ so there is an upward acceleration.
II could be correct – Balloon could be moving upwards - acceleration is also upwards so speed of the balloon would be increasing.
III could be correct – Balloon could be moving downwards - acceleration is upwards so speed of the balloon would be decreasing (deceleration).
For linear motion, acceleration tells us nothing about the speed, just how the speed is changing. The balloon could be moving upwards, moving downwards or stationary.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
A car is travelling along a straight line for a total time of 100 s. Throughout this time the driving force provided by the car is 1.2 kN and the total resistive force acting on the car is 500 N.
Which row correctly shows the rate of change of momentum and the impulse of the car during the 100 s.

Rate of change of momentumImpulse$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^0}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^4}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^1}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^5}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Newton's second law states that net force = rate of change of momentum.
Therefore, the rate of change of momentum is simply the net force acting on the car


- $\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=1200$ N - 500 N = 700 N = 700 kg m s$^{-2}=7 \times 10^2$ kg m s$^{-2}$

Impulse


- $J$ = $F_{net}\Delta t$ = (700)(100) = 7 $\times$ $10{^4}$ kg m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
An airplane in straight level flight experiences a lift force $L$ that is proportional to the speed of the plane and is perpendicular to the axis of the wings and as shown in diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c2732ed-647d-4792-be74-712a22b4cca5/images/5e5ef892-8432-4443-8a10-38ebaa5e28cf/PH0630zza.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by Alvin Hikmawan from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$

On a banked turn at the same speed, the wings make a small angle $\theta$ with the horizontal.
Which of the following is the best estimate of the centripetal force on the airplane?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $L$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $L\cos\theta$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $L\sin\theta\ $
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $W\cos\theta\ $
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Note that the angle that the wings make with the horizontal is equivalent to the angle that the tail of the plane makes with the vertical.
On the turn, the lift force makes an angle of $\theta$ with the vertical.
The centripetal force will act towards the centre of the circular path. In this case, it is the horizontal component of the lifting force.
This is given by $L\sin\theta$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c2732ed-647d-4792-be74-712a22b4cca5/images/74c017cd-b585-4cdd-8eb8-163adea399a0/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.23.51%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by Alvin Hikmawan from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
An object of mass 3 kg is traveling at velocity of +10 m s$^{-1}$  horizontally. The object explodes into two fragments of mass 1 kg and 2 kg. After explosion, the 1 kg fragment has a horizontal velocity of +30 m s$^{-1}$ and a vertical velocity +20 m s$^{-1}$. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/726d8f7f-c38d-4f90-846a-264dc5f9390d/images/74ebdb9c-e95a-4274-b0e1-cfcf6b470874/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.20.48%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly shows the horizontal and vertical components of the momentum of the 2 kg fragment after the explosion?
Assume no external forces act on the object.

Horizontal momentum / $\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}$Vertical momentum / $\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $-30$ $-10$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $-30$ $-20$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$0$-10$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$0$-20$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Momentum is conserved in an isolated system so here momentum before collision = momentum after collision.
Horizontal and vertical directions are independent, momentum is conserved in both.
$\textbf{In the horizontal direction}$:
Initial momentum $= mv=(3)(10)=30$ kg m s$^{-1}$
Final momentum $= 30 =(1)(30)+$ horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment
Horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment $=0$
$\textbf{In the vertical direction}$:
Initial momentum $=0$
Final momentum $= 0 =(1)(20)+$ horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment
Horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment = $-20$ kg m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
A block of mass 16 kg is pushed and released along a rough horizontal surface at an initial speed of 2 m s$^{-1}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c45a6b1-fd52-47f4-87cf-51ddb2c7383c/images/0f148f8c-b290-441d-943e-e1bc0eba3a33/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.30.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The block travels through a distance of 16 m and is brought to rest. What is the magnitude of the frictional force that brings the block to rest?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2 N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 4 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 8 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 16 N
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The net work done on the block 
= Change in kinetic energy of the block
$\begin{aligned}
 W_{net}&=\Delta E_k \\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 Fs \cos(\theta)& = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\Fs\cos(\theta) &= 0 -\frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(\cos\,180^o)&=-\frac{1}{2}(16)(2)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(-1)&=-32 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
F&=2\textrm{ N}\
\end{aligned}$
Alternative:


- $v^2 = u^2 + 2as \Rightarrow a = \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2s} = \dfrac{0^2 - 2^2}{2(16)} = -0.125$ m s$^{-2}$
- $|F| = m|a| = 16|-0.125| = 2$ N

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Two trucks X and Y are pulling a car out of thick mud along a straight path. The only other horizontal force acting on the car is a drag force opposite to the direction of motion. The diagram shows a top view of the direction of the force applied by truck $X$ and the direction of motion of the car.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/799656dd-0ea3-431e-9ae2-ec036fc0097a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.09%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following vectors shows the direction of the force applied by truck $Y$?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/af518a6b-1c74-4e1c-9e25-c26470c9ae43/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.19%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The motion of the car here is in the direction of the sum of the two forces vectors from $X$ and $Y$. 
The only vector that will add to vector $X$ to produce a net force vector to the right is one in the direction of C.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/039af546-0a6a-489b-aa52-94a641645c42/images/e3fe004e-d88c-4539-9390-2d8f35066f14/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.26.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
A box is sliding down an incline at a constant speed of $2$ m s$^{-1}$. The angle of the incline is $\theta$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18595241-7849-4c02-a19c-712cdb369317/images/bbdade18-80b2-4de8-9c03-a0393cd56ca3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.28.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The magnitude of the total of the opposing forces is $16$ N. What is the force of gravity acting on the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\sin\theta}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\cos\theta}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\cos\theta}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The box is moving at a constant speed. According to Newton’s First Law, the resultant force acting on the box must be zero. The free body diagram of the forces acting on the box:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18595241-7849-4c02-a19c-712cdb369317/images/fb785bfc-58f2-4616-b01f-1014614efe2a/PH0547-1.png)


Weight ($F_g$) has two components (shown in red): perpendicular to the slope and parallel to the slope. From the diagram:


- $F_g\cos\theta=F_N \hspace{2em}$ and $\hspace{2em}F_g\sin\theta=16$

Therefore


- $F_g=\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
A rocket ejects hot gas in space in a direction opposite to its travelling direction. What is correct for the magnitude of the momentum and the kinetic energy of the rocket?

MomentumKinetic Energy$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ConservedConserved$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$IncreasedConserved$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ConservedIncreased$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$IncreasedIncreased
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The rocket is not a closed system. The reaction force from ejecting hot gas will increasingly accelerate the rocket, hence both momentum and kinetic energy will increase.

list.title: Question 28
list.content: - - An object of mass 10 kg is released from rest. The object explodes into three fragments X, Y and Z after falling a distance of 46 m. Show that the momentum of the object just before the explosion is around 300 kg m s$^{-1}$. [2] Assume air resistance is negligible. - Discuss whether mechanical energy is conserved in an explosion. [2] - Immediately after the explosion, fragment X has a mass of 2 kg and a velocity of 50 m s$^{-1}$ to the right. Fragment Y has a mass of 3 kg and velocity of 10 m s$^{-1}$ vertically upwards. Fragment Z has a velocity $v$ at an angle $\theta$ below the horizontal. This is illustrated below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1fc33507-f144-4e05-9e3d-1383d0ad8217/images/7d2bbad3-dc57-4612-a414-a1ba4aecec68/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%2011.30.57%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - Show that the vertical component of $v$ is approximately 70 m s$^{-1}$. [3] - Calculate $v$. [2] - Determine $\theta$. [2] - After the explosion the 2 kg fragment falls a distance $h$ and collides with a stationary trolley on the flat horizontal ground. This collision causes the trolley to move with a velocity $V$. Explain why $V$ independent of $h$. [2] Air resistance is negligible.
list.markScheme:
- 
  - ($v^2=u^2+2as$  or $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2=mgh$) and $p=mv$ $\checkmark$
    $p=mv=10\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=\answer{300\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}}$     $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    
    
    - $v^2=u^2+2as $

    Initial velocity $u=0$ and acceleration $a=9.8\textrm{ m s}^{-2}$
    
    
    - $v=\sqrt{2as}=\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=30.02$
    - $p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}$

    $\underline{\textrm{Alternatively}}$
    
    
    - $\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=mgh$
    - $\dfrac{1}{2}v^2=gh$
    - $v=\sqrt{2gh}=\sqrt{(2)(9.8)(46)}=30.02 $
    - $p=mv=(10)(30.02)=300.2\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}$

    
  - Chemical/potential energy is released from the object / converted to kinetic energy / kinetic energy increases $\checkmark$
    Mechanical energy is sum of kinetic and gravitational potential energy therefore it is not conserved $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Momentum and energy are always conserved.
    In an explosion momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not. Total energy is still conserved. Chemical or potential energy can be stored inside objects. When a chemical reaction that releases energy takes place inside an object, this energy can be transferred into kinetic energy of the object (or objects if it is split into fragments).
    Mechanical energy is sum of kinetic and gravitational potential and the total mechanical energy increases in the explosion, therefore it is not conserved
    

- 
  - Mass of Z = 5 kg $\checkmark$
    $(-10)(3)+ \text{vertical momentum of Z} = 300\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    $v_{vertical}=\dfrac{330}{5}=\answer{66\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Mass will be conserved here so Z has a mass of $10-2-3=5$ kg
    Momentum is conserved in the vertical direction.
    
    
    - Vertical momentum before explosion = vertical momentum after explosion (taking downwards as positive)
    - $300=$ vertical momentum of X $+$ vertical momentum of Z
    - $300=(3)(-10)+(5)(v_{vertical})$
    - $300+30=(5)(v_{vertical})$
    - $\dfrac{330}{5}=v_{vertical}$
    - $v_{vertical}=66\textrm{ m s}^{-1}$

    
  - $0=(2)(-50)+(5)(v_{horizontal})$
    Giving horizontal velocity of Z $= 20\textrm{ m s}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    Speed $= \sqrt{20^2+66^2}=\answer{69\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Momentum is conserved in the horizontal direction.
    
    
    - Horizontal momentum before explosion = horizontal momentum after collision (taking left as positive)
    - $0=$ horizontal momentum of X $+$ horizontal momentum of Z
    - $0=(2)(-50)+(5)(v_{horizontal}) $
    - $100=5v_{horizontal }$
    - $v_{horizontal}=20\textrm{ m s}^{-1}$

    Speed $v$ is the vector sum of the vertical and horizontal velocities.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1fc33507-f144-4e05-9e3d-1383d0ad8217/images/578ebdc7-70bd-4e7b-93d1-bce303324731/image.png)


    Using Pythagoras
    
    
    - $v=\sqrt{20^2+66^2}=68.96\textrm{ m s}^{-1} $

    
  - $\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{66}{20}$ or $\sin{\theta}=\dfrac{66}{69}$ or $\sin{\theta}=\dfrac{20}{69}$ (allow any equivalent fractions) $\checkmark$
    $\theta = \answer{73\,\degree}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
We can use the vector triangle along with the relation $\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}$ to deduce that $\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{66}{20}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1fc33507-f144-4e05-9e3d-1383d0ad8217/images/a2da154f-1312-429b-88ea-2bcf2757bedf/image.png)


    
    
    - $\theta = \tan^{-1}{\dfrac{66}{20}} = 73.1\degree$

    

- The horizontal velocity of the fragment will be independent of height / remain the same because acceleration due to gravity is purely vertical/downwards. $\checkmark$
  (When the fragment collides with the trolley) only horizontal momentum is transferred to the trolley / trolley is unable to move in vertical direction / vertical momentum will be transferred to ground/Earth. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Horizontal and vertical dimensions are independent. The fragment will follow a projectile path. Its vertical velocity will increase, and its horizontal velocity will remain the same.
  The trolley's motion is restricted in the vertical direction due to the ground, so the vertical momentum of the fragment will be transferred to the Earth and the trolley - relative to the Earth the trolley will not move in the vertical direction. Horizontal momentum of the fragment will be transferred to the trolley causing it to move along the flat ground.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
A table tennis ball of mass $m$ is dropped on a level surface from a height $H$. The ball rebounds to a height $h < H$ after impact. Air resistance on the ball is negligible. Which of the following is correct about the nature of the collision and magnitude of the change in momentum ($\Delta p$) of the ball as a result of this impact?

Nature of the collisionChange in momentum $\Delta p$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Elastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Inelastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C. $\hspace{1.5em}$Elastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D. $\hspace{1.5em}$Inelastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The height of rebound is less than the height of release. This is evidence that some energy is dissipated at the point of impact. Hence inelastic.
We can use conservation of energy to find the velocity upon impact:


- $mgH=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2$
- $u^2 =2gH$
- $u=\sqrt{2gH} $

Similarly, the velocity just after impact is: $v=-\sqrt{2gh} \hspace{2em}$
Where the negative sign represents the opposite direction to $u$ (upwards)


- $\therefore \Delta p=|mv-mu|$
- $=|m(v-u)|$
- $=m|(-\sqrt{2gh}-\sqrt{2gH})|$

Removing the absolute value gives


- $=m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$

list.title: Question 30
list.content: - Define distance. [1] - An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distance d with time t is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/ec0aad4a-2afd-42a6-8ebe-1a8af181242f/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.47.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - Describe the motion of the object between $t=0.5$ s and $t=1.0$ s. The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    The gradient of the tangent line =$\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=18$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient $\checkmark$
    Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.
    The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.
    
  - The final momentum is less than the initial momentum $\checkmark$
    Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentum $p_f$ is less than the initial $p_i$ momentum. The change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    
    
    - $\Delta p=p_f-p_i$

    since $p_i$ > $p_f$, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
A block of mass $m$, initially at rest, is acted upon by two unequal forces $F_1$ and $F_2$ such that $F_1 > F_2$ as shown in the diagram below. The forces act for a time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a17f325-0730-4c7d-bdc2-c73879e21d20/images/b90314d9-4485-4028-b59e-64dc6ecf61ff/PH0266.png)


Which of the following correctly represents the magnitude of the final velocity of the block after time $t$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\bigg(\dfrac{F_1+F_2}{m}\bigg)(t)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\bigg(\dfrac{F_1-F_2}{m}\bigg)(t)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\bigg(\dfrac{F_2-F_1}{m}\bigg)(t)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\bigg(\dfrac{F_1-F_2}{t}\bigg)(m)$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since $F_1$ is greater than $F_2$, net force will be $F_1-F_2$ in the direction of $F_1$.
Using this value of net force, acceleration $a$ is


- $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}= \dfrac{F_1-F_2}{m}$

Using this value of $a$ in the expression $v=u+at$ and taking $u = 0$, we obtain the final velocity.
OR


- $\Delta p = F_{net}\Delta t. \hspace{2em}$



- $m\Delta v = F_{net}\Delta t. \hspace{2em} $



- $\Delta v = \bigg(\dfrac{F_1-F_2}{m}\bigg)(t)$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
A cargo container is released from an airplane. A parachute is opened remotely a few seconds later to land it safely. Which graph shows the variation of the vertical acceleration $a$ with time $t$ for the cargo container from when it leaves the plane until landing?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/008093a4-5c1e-419d-865d-2fad91185b6a/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.24%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/b3a16c1d-d1dc-48dd-832f-9535acc8b644/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/e5911411-0db3-4109-bfcf-712ac30be345/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.50%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/3bf1ed62-d84b-4b48-a897-cdec1945761d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The cargo starts with large negative (downward) acceleration. As the cargo container falls, it is speeding up; as it is speeding up, drag force increases, so the acceleration decreases until the cargo container reaches a terminal speed where acceleration is zero. After the parachute is opened, drag force will increase, which is greater than the weight of the cargo container, causing an opposite, upwards, acceleration (deceleration). As the cargo container slows down the drag force decreases, so the net force decreases, and acceleration decreases again until the cargo container reaches a lower terminal speed where acceleration is zero and the forces are balanced.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
A car enters a roundabout with a speed $v$. The dotted line shows the path of the car. The road is slightly banked inward at an angle to the horizontal.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46047306-4c31-4e50-8ee4-a0671285fe55/images/8bef058b-da21-4259-8e52-70155256bcbb/PH0298-1.png)


The coefficient of friction between the tires of the car and the road is $\mu$. When $\mu$ decreases, which of the following changes could prevent the car from slipping away on this roundabout?

$\hspace{1em}$ Banking angle of the turn $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{3em}$ Speed of the car$\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$increaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$increasedecrease$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreasedecrease
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When $\mu$ decreases, the maximum possible frictional force decreases. Friction acts along with the component of the normal force in the horizontal direction to produce the centripetal force. To account for this change, decreasing the speed will allow the car to require less frictional force due to a lower required centripetal acceleration and safely take the turn.


- $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\mu mg$

Increasing the banking angle increases the component of the normal force that points towards the centre of the circle, providing more centripetal force to compensate for the loss in centripetal force contribution from friction. Remember that in this situation friction is acting towards the centre of the circle, and so having an increased component of the normal force acting towards the centre of the circle will $\lq$help' friction to turn the car.

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
A car makes a U-turn on a flat horizontal road at a speed of 9 m s$^{-1}$ as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4e45e80c-797e-4f19-a8c4-647f5b2242d6/images/7c887e9f-be44-423f-81d5-6571465eee30/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%205.29.58%E2%80%AFPM.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$
The inner radius of the U-turn, $r_1$, is $4$ m and its outer radius, $r_2$  is $10$ m.
What is the best estimate for minimum acceleration of the car when making the U-turn?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $0.9$ m s$^{-2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $2.2$ m s$^{-2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $8.1$ m s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $20.2$ m s$^{-2}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Centripetal acceration is given by


- $a=\dfrac{v^2}{r}$

The minimum acceleration is at the largest radius.
The centripetal acceleration:


- $a=\dfrac{9^2}{10}=8.1$ m s$^{-2}$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
An object with a weight $W$ connected to one end of a rod of negligible mass rotates at constant speed in a vertical plane.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/51f2e4d1-787c-4b55-bf29-fb6b924bf7bd/images/3c969e82-6e66-4e40-9546-9680f77d93a8/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%201.50.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


When the object is at the top position of the circular path, the tension on the rod is zero. What is the magnitude of tension at the bottom position of the circular path?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Equal to $W$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Smaller than $W$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Equal to $2W$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Greater than $2W$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At the top position


- $T + W=F_{centripetal}$ and $T = 0$

Therefore,


- $F_{centripetal} = W$

At the bottom


- $T - W  =  F_{centripetal}$

Since speed is constant:


- $F_{centripetal} = W$

Therefore, the tension at the bottom


- $T = 2W$

list.title: Question 36
list.content: - A suitcase of mass $12$ kg is placed on the top of a car. Both the car and the suitcase are initially at rest. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/528619d6-1a59-4363-9256-f7f9a49ee283/images/416db747-14d1-40de-b552-c2fcc8af79c2/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.51.37%E2%80%AFPM.png) The car begins to move with increasing acceleration. The suitcase accelerates along with the car until its acceleration reaches $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$, at which point the suitcase just starts to slide towards the back of the car. - Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the car and the suitcase. [2] - If the car were to continue accelerating at $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$, explain why the suitcase's acceleration relative to the ground would be less than $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$. [2] - The car stops suddenly, and the suitcase continues moving forwards. When it loses contact with the car, the velocity of the suitcase is $4.5$ m s$^{-1}$ relative to the ground in the horizontal direction. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/528619d6-1a59-4363-9256-f7f9a49ee283/images/f6901e81-4e86-4e92-980b-65b3d742b139/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.49.00%E2%80%AFPM.png) The height of the car is $1.5$ m. The suitcase does not rotate as it falls, and air resistance is negligible. - Show that the time taken for the suitcase to hit the ground is around $0.6$ s. [1] - Calculate the speed at which the suitcase hits the ground. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Frictional force / $\mu_s F_N$ / $\mu_s mg\ =(12)(2.5)$ $\checkmark$
Equates frictional force to net force to get $\mu_s\ =\ \dfrac{2.5}{9.8}\ =$ $0.26$ $ \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The only force acting on the suitcase in the horizontal direction is friction. This friction causes the suitcase to accelerate to the right (relative to the ground).
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/528619d6-1a59-4363-9256-f7f9a49ee283/images/9cddd7b9-63d8-4382-83e7-637c117ab2f9/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.54.57%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    When the suitcase is at rest relative to the car its acceleration is the same as that of the car so using
    
    
    - $F_{net} = ma$

    We can say that
    
    
    - $F_f = (8) (\ce{acceleration\ of\ the\ car})$

    Frictional force between two objects when there is no relative motion between the objects is given by $F_f \leq \mu_s F_N$
    When the object is on the point of motion, the static friction force is at a maximum and we can say that $F_f = \mu_s F_N$
    The suitcase just starts to slide when the acceleration of the car is $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$ so we can say that
    
    
    - $\mu_s F_N = ma = (12) (2.5)$

    Vertical forces are balanced so reaction force is equal to weight.
    
    
    - $\mu_s mg = (12) (2.5)$
    - $\mu_s (12) (9.8) = (12) (2.5)$

    Cancelling a factor of 12 and rearranging for $\mu_s$ gives
    
    
    - $\mu_s (9.8) = (2.5)$
    - $\mu_s = \dfrac{2.5}{9.8}\ =\ 0.26$

    
  - Maximum static coefficient of friction > dynamic / kinetic coefficient of friction / $\mu_s\ >\ \mu_d$ $\checkmark$
    Force of dynamic / kinetic friction will be less than the force of static friction $\checkmark$\
    OR
    Once in motion frictional force will be less than $(mass\ of\ suitcase)\ \times\ (acceleration\ of\ car)$ so suitcase accelerates forwards at a slower rate than the car $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Frictional force between two objects when there is no relative motion between the objects is given by $F_f\ \leq\ \mu_s F_N$
    Frictional force between two objects when there is relative motion between the objects is given by $F_f\ =\ \mu_d F_N$
    $\mu_s\ >\ \mu_d$ so $\mu_s R\ >\ \mu_d R$ when the object begins the move the frictional force becomes smaller.
    To move with the car the net force on the suitcase must be $= (7) (2.5)$
    But $\mu_d F_N < \mu_s F_N = (7)(2.5)$
    So, the suitcase accelerates forwards at a slower rate than the car (So relative to the car the suitcase accelerates backwards).
    

- 
  - $\hspace{1.5em}$ $s\ =\ ut\ +\ \dfrac{1}{2}at^2\ =\dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
    
    
    - $t\ =\ \sqrt{\dfrac{2s}{a}}\ =\ \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(1.5)}{9.8}}\ =$       $0.55$ s $\checkmark$

    Must see extra significant figure for mark.
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
We can treat the horizontal and vertical dimensions independently.
    In the vertical dimension we know the following:
    
    
    - (displacement) $s\ =\ 1.5$ m
    - (initial velocity) $u\ =\ 0$
    - (acceleration) $a\ =\ 9.8$ m s$^{-2}$

    We can therefore use the following equation to find time taken
    
    
    - $s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$

    Substituting in our values gives:
    
    
    - $1.5 = (0)(t) + \dfrac{1}{2}\ (9.8)t^2$
    - $1.5 =\dfrac{1}{2} (9.8)t^2$

    Rearranging for $t$:
    
    
    - $(2)(1.5) = (9.8)t^2$
    - $t^2 = \dfrac{(2)(1.5)}{9.8}$
    - $t = \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(1.5)}{9.8}}\ =\ 0.55$ s (2sf)

    
  - $\hspace{1.5em}$ $(v_y)^2\ =\ u^2\ +\ \dfrac{2as}{v_y}\ =\ u\ +\ at$
    
    
    - $(v_y)^2\ =\ (0)^2\ +\ (2)\ (9.8)\ (1.5)\ =29.4$\

    OR
    
    
    - $v_y\ =\ (9.8)\ (0.55)\ =5.4$ m s$^{-1}\ $ seen $\checkmark$
    - speed $= \sqrt{(v_y)^2 + (v_x)^2}\ = \sqrt{29.4 + 4.5^2}\ =$ $7.0$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

    Allow full marks for use of $t = 0.6\,s$ giving a final answer of $speed = 7.4$ m s$^{-1}$
    Alternative:
    Energy is conserved
    
    
    - $\dfrac{1}{2}m(v_{final})^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}m(v_{initial})^2 + mgh$ $\checkmark$
    - $\dfrac{1}{2}(v_{final})^2\ = \dfrac{1}{2}(4.5)^2 + (9.8) (1.5)$
    - $v_{final}\ =\ \sqrt{4.5^2 + (2) (9.8) (1.5)} =$ $7.0$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Speed is the magnitude of velocity. The velocity of the suitcase will have a horizontal and a vertical component when it hits the ground.
    The horizontal velocity of the suitcase remains constant as there are no horizontal forces acting on the suitcase as it falls so $v_x\ =\ 4.5$ m s$^{-1}$.
    In the vertical dimension we know the following:
    
    
    - (displacement) $s = 1.5$ m
    - (initial velocity) $u = 0$
    - (acceleration) $a = 9.8$ m s$^{-2}$
    - (time) $t = 0.55$ s

    It's best to use information given in the question so selecting the equation $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$
    
    
    - $(v_y)^2 = (0)^2 + (2) (9.8) (1.5) = 29.4$
    - $v_y = \sqrt{29.4} = 5.42\ (3sf)$

    Now speed $v_{total}$ is the magnitude of the vector sum of $v_x$ and $v_y$ ($v_x$ and $v_y$ are perpendicular so we can use Pythagoras' theorem)
    
    
    - $(v_{total})^2\ =\ (v_y)^2\ +\ (v_x)^2$
    - $v_{total} = \sqrt{(v_y)^2 + (v_x)^2} = \sqrt{(5.42 …)^2 + 4.5^2} = \sqrt{29.4 + 4.5^2} = 7.0$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 37
list.content: - A ball of mass $0.20$ kg moving on a frictionless horizontal plane collides elastically with a vertical wall. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/2895dd52-b8a7-4f2a-8e01-1d5ff5c6a617/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.32.51%E2%80%AFPM.png) The variation of the force $F$ acting on the ball during the collision with time $t$ is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/670df608-825b-4b06-9083-411840c17cbf/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.13.31%E2%80%AFPM.png) The speed of the ball just before the impact is $5.0$ m s$^{-1}$. Calculate the maximum force exerted on the wall by the ball. [3] - The wall is covered with a coating that causes an inelastic collision. The ball hits the wall with the same initial speed and bounces back with a speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$. - Explain, by considering the moments just before and after the collision, how the principle of conservation of energy applies to the collision. [2] - Calculate the loss of the energy of the ball during the collision. [2] - During this collision, the ball undergoes a change in momentum. Discuss whether the the law of conservation of momentum applies in this situation. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Change in momentum = $\left(0.20\right)\left(5.0\right)-\left(0.20\right)\left(-5.0\right)=2.0$ kg m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  The area under the graph=change in momentum  $\checkmark$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $F_{max}=\dfrac{(2.0)(2)}{(10\times{10}^{-3})}$ = $400$ N $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the graph gives the change in momentum $\Delta p$;
  $\hspace{2em}$ Area = $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=\Delta p$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta p=mv-mu$
  The ball moves in the opposite direction after the collision
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta p=mv-mu$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=(0.20)(5.0)-(0.20)(-5.0)$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=2.0$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $F_{max}=\dfrac{(2.0)(2)}{(10\times{10}^{-3})}=400$ N
  
- 
  - Loss of kinetic energy of the ball $\checkmark$
Equals to the increase in internal energy of the objects and surroundings $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The law of conservation of energy states that in any interaction, energy is not created or destroyed. In this situation, although the ball loses kinetic energy overall, this energy is transferred to thermal energy in the surroundings during the collision.
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(5.0\right)^2=2.5$ J
    and
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(3.0\right)^2=0.9$ J $\checkmark$
    $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta E_K=2.5-0.9$ = $1.6$ J $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The kinetic energy of the ball $E_{K_i}$ before the collision:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{K_i}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(5.0\right)^2=2.5$ J
    The kinetic energy of the ball $E_{K_f}$ after the collision:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{K_f}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(3.0\right)^2=0.9$ J
    The kinetic energy lost $\Delta E_{K}$:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta E_{K}=2.5-0.9=1.6$ J
    
  - Law states that momentum of a closed system is constant in the absence of external forces. $\checkmark$
    Considering the ball only, the wall exerts an external force therefore its momentum changes.
    OR
    System incorporates the ball and the wall. The change of momentum of the ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the wall/earth $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
A brick of weight $100$ N rests on a rough horizontal surface. A varying horizontal force is applied to the brick. The graph shows the variation of the magnitude of the frictional force with the magnitude of the applied force.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/64067065-6e8b-4d0c-843f-45ceb9e213b9/images/b43d2c76-cb43-4b97-8113-985637836110/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.09.59%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the coefficient of the dynamic friction between the brick and the rough surface?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ 0.2
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ 0.3
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ 0.4
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ 0.5
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The dynamic friction between two surfaces occurs when there is a relative motion between them. It has a fixed value and it can be found by


- $F_f=\mu_dF_N$

The graph shows the static friction force increasing linearly to a maxiumum until the object starts to slip and dynamic friction replaces static friction. According to the graph, the magnitude of the dynamic friction (the fixed value on the graph) is $40$ N.
By considering


- $F_g=F_N$

We can substitute $F_N=100$ N and $F_f=40$ N into the friction equation as follows:


- $F_f=\mu_dF_N$
- $40\,N=\mu_d$ (100 N)
- $0.40=\mu_d$

Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
A box of weight $400$ N is placed on a scale in an elevator. The scale reads $300$ N.
Which of the following is correct about the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the elevator?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ Magnitude $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ Direction $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $0.25$ m s$^{-2}$Upwards$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $0.25$ m s$^{-2}$Downwards$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$Upwards$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2.5$ m s$^{-2}$Downwards
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The scale's reading represents the upward force on the box from the scale. It is less than the weight, which means that the elevator is accelerating downwards.
The weight of the box is given as $400$ N
Mass can be found through


- $W=mg$
- $400 = m(10)$
- $m=40$ kg

Resolving the forces and using Newton's Second Law gives
$\hspace{1em}$ $\Sigma F = ma$
$\hspace{1em}$ $400-300=(40)a$
$\hspace{1em}$ $a=2.5$ m s$^{-2}$

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving horizontally strikes a vertical wall with a speed of 30 m s$^{-1}$. The magnitude of the change of the momentum of the ball is 22.5 kg m s$^{-1}$. Calculate the speed of the ball just after it rebounds.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8425ea05-2617-4ded-b0e9-edb297fa635a/images/d1c76c1d-7e5f-4b4f-b398-e74b073c46a5/PH0247.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5 m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in momentum;


- $\Delta p = p_f - p_i$

The momentum in the left direction is regarded as negative while the right is positive. Therefore;
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.8
cm}-\Delta p &= -p_f - p_i\\
-\Delta p &= -mv - mu\\
-22.5 &= -0.5v - (0.5)(30)\\
0.5v &= 22.5 - 15\\
0.5v &= 7.5\\
v &= 15\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
An object is moving at constant velocity. Which of the following could be the free-body diagram representing the forces acting on the object?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/eac264c7-d1db-40ca-9df7-0a940c89da3e/PH0551A.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/0c531ffc-7efc-4728-a534-377c94f919d3/PH0551B.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/87d3123b-25d6-4429-8b36-070257af8e77/PH0551C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/619e936c-9974-4e07-be59-34be253c1bdb/PH0551D.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to Newton’s First Law, when the resultant force acting on the object is zero, acceleration will be zero and the velocity of the object is constant.  When head to tail method is applied to add the three vectors of option C, the following is obtained.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/846d5eb3-bc3e-4b0c-9869-00bbc6e23732/images/d8f0a7fb-48a1-42c3-83c0-d6752adc3475/PH0551MS.png)


The closed triangle represents a resultant force of zero.
Hence, the correct answer is C.

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
An egg hits a wall covered with a soft material and sticks to it. The graph shows the variation of horizontal force $F$ acting on the egg with time $t$ during the collision.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/ee6eba17-bae2-471b-bcae-5d464a02e193/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.31.57%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The soft material on the wall is removed and an identical egg with the same initial speed collides with and sticks to the wall. Which graph shows the variation of horizontal force $F$ acting on the second egg with time $t$ during the collision?  The graph for the first egg is shown as a dotted line.
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b5075853-1b1f-472d-aead-c9bfe18c774d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.39o%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/b3bbeb20-fd49-439b-a4b3-1ac892f72c3d/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/03ad81b3-f121-4564-83dd-4c55450dd162/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c58a3655-499a-4418-8936-9ffbdcad1b75/images/a2b278fe-7a8f-4e28-a65d-071c6595dcd5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.32.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to colliding with a hard surface instead of a soft surface, the time for the collision will be much less. Since the egg hits the wall with the same velocity and stops in both situations, the change in momentum of the egg is the same for both collisions. The area under a force-time graph gives the change in momentum for an object. Thus the areas under the graphs should be equal.
By using Newton’s second law


- $F_{avg}=\Delta p\Delta t$
- $\Delta t = \dfrac{\Delta p}{F_{avg}}$

According to this relationship, a shorter time of collision will result in a greater average force and also greater peak force. This is shown in graph A.

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
The diagram below shows a person of mass 80 kg standing in an elevator of mass 800 kg. The elevator accelerates upwards at a rate of 1.2 m s$^{-2}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/7092be56-0665-4bb1-9771-f5bf4603bece/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.46.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


What is the normal contact force exerted on the person by the elevator?


- A. $\hspace{1em} $ 96 N
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ 690 N
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ 780 N
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ 880 N
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
There are two forces acting on the person - Weight and normal contact force. The lift is accelerating upwards so there must be a net force upwards.  Below is a free body diagram showing these forces.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f33b5a1c-0d63-4e7e-b7c5-585e9bd20232/images/744a0134-dee2-4a34-a2e2-0bcb76f19d03/PH0932Ans.png)


Net force = $ma$
Normal contact force $-$ Weight = $ma$
Normal contact force = $mg + ma = m(g + a) = 80(9.8 + 1.2) = 80(11) = 880$ N
$\underline{\textrm{Further intuition}}$:
The normal contact force is the upward force felt by the person in the elevator. The person will feel heavier when the elevator is accelerating upwards.
Normal contact force = $m(g+a)$ will be true for any $a$ if we take upwards acceleration as positive.
$\underline{\textrm{Examples:}}$
When $a = 0$ (the elevator is stationary), normal contact force = $mg$
When $a$ is negative (the elevator is accelerating downwards) normal contact force = $m(g - a)$
When $a = -g$ (elevator is in freefall) normal contact force = 0

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
A roller coaster passes a vertical loop in a constant gravitational field. Friction and air resistance are negligible.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f9fbca55-1d2f-4718-ad75-58d48d2e356d/images/0cf089b7-2bb6-4ec1-80b9-460ea82b2837/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.26.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



How do the kinetic energy of the roller coaster and the normal reaction force acting on the roller coaster compare at point X and Y?

$\hspace{1.75em}$ kinetic energy $\hspace{1.75em}$ $\hspace{1em}$ normal reaction force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$greater at X than Ygreater at Y than X$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$greater at Y than Xgreater at X than Y$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$greater at Y than Xgreater at Y than X$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$greater at X than Ygreater at X than Y
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
By conservation of energy, the roller coaster has greater kinetic energy at the bottom of the loop (X), then kinetic energy is converted to gravitational potential energy at the top of the loop (Y). Hence B and C are rejected.
The normal reaction force by the track contributes to the centripetal force needed for the roller coaster to move along the loop. Since centripetal force increases with speed, the normal reaction force is larger at the bottom of the loop (X), when speed is greater. At the bottom of the loop, the normal reaction force is also the sum of the centripetal force and the weight of the roller coaster, while at the top of the loop the centripetal force is normal force is equal to the centripetal force minus the gravitational force.

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
An object of mass $m$ rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass $M$ is connected to it with a rope.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/6c42ecf6-21ee-4fb7-a6b8-4bbfd1f21450/PH0541-1.png)


The image below shows the free-body diagram of horizontal forces on the object of mass $m$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e1a53fc-8a87-47ba-a519-cfe28bebbadc/images/803b1ee4-7847-4dcb-abd1-2fa5525ae946/PH0541-2.png)


Which of the following correctly describes the Newton's 3rd Law force paired with $F_2$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ 	The pull of mass $m$ upwards on the earth.
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ 	The upward contact force acting on the mass $m$.
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ 	The tension force to the right acting on the mass $m$.
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ The friction force to the right acting on the surface.
list.markScheme:
D


$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the given diagram, two horizontal forces are acting on the mass $m$. They are friction and tension. The force acting towards the left, represented by $F_2$, is friction. The friction occurs on the object due to sliding on the surface. Therefore, according to Newton's third law, the pair of the force must be on the surface and in the opposite direction. Therefore, the answer is D.

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
A trolley is pushed in a level parking area of a market on a very rainy day. The rain fills the trolley at a rate of $R$ kg s$^{-1}$. Ignoring frictional forces, what is the force needed to move the trolley at a constant speed of $v$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\ R v$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{R}{v}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{v}{R}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	R+v$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
As water enters the trolley, a force is needed to increase the water’s horizontal momentum so that it is moving at the same speed as the trolley.
We are given that the rate at which the water enters the trolley is $R$, so


- $R=\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}$

The force F acting on the trolley:


- $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}$
- $F=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

Since $v$ is constant,


- $F=v \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} \hspace{2em}$  where $\hspace{2em}\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=R$
- $F=R v$

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
A box with a mass of M rests on a balance in an elevator that is moving downwards. The elevator slows with an acceleration of   $\dfrac{g}{4}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/668949a1-7b88-4532-bf3c-3689bdf6f746/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.23.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following gives the reading of the balance?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5Mg}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	Mg$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3Mg}{4}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{Mg}{2}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The reading of the balance is equal to the magnitude of the reaction force. The free-body diagram of the box M:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/93aad0fb-70d9-4742-9503-89c79a83c9b5/PH0543-2.png)


Since the elevator slows down downwards, the acceleration must be upwards and the normal reaction force ($F_N)$ must be greater than the weight ($F_g$). According to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:


- $F_N - F_g = ma$

When the given expressions are substituted:


- $F_N - Mg=M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)$
- $F_N = M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)+Mg$
- $F_N = \dfrac{5Mg}{4}$

Therefore, the answer is A.

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
Two blocks of masses $m$ and $2m$ approach each other and collide on a horizontal smooth surface. After the collision, they move together. The speeds of the blocks before the collision are $5v$ and $2v$ as shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f19e4d29-0626-4d4e-860f-091ac4774da8/images/e2a5e8eb-26c4-4918-8298-bcc5c293080c/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.36.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly gives the speed of the blocks after the collision and the nature of the collision?

Speed after collisionNature of collision$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $3v$Elastic$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$Elastic$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $3v$Inelastic$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$Inelastic
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
According to the principle of conservation of momentum, the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after the collision.
As the blocks are moving in opposite directions, a sign convention is introduced where motion to the right is positive.


- $p_{initial} = p_{final}$
- $m(5v)+2m\left(-2v\right)=3mv_f$  where $v_f$ is the speed of the blocks after the collision
- $mv=3mv_f$
- $\dfrac{v}{3}=v_f$

The initial total kinetic energy of the blocks before the collision $E_{ki}$:


- $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}m{(5v)}^2+\dfrac{1}{2}2m{(2v)}^2$
- $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(33mv^2)$

The total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision $E_{kf}$:


- $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(3m){\bigg(\dfrac{v}{3}\bigg)}^2$
- $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{6}mv^2$

The total kinetic energy is conserved in elastic collisions while it is not conserved in inelastic collisions.  Since the total kinetic energy before the collision is less than the total kinetic energy of the blocks after the collision, the collision is inelastic.
(In any collision where objects “stick together” the situation is an inelastic collision.)

list.title: Question 49
list.content: A solid sphere of mass $m$ is released from rest below the surface of oil and moves downwards. - Draw the free body diagram of the sphere at the instant it was released. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/5abc5ee9-e827-4a82-8625-f76a3d1c9c85/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.33.43%E2%80%AFPM.png) - - Show that the terminal speed of the sphere is given by: $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$ where $\rho_s$ is the density of the sphere and $\rho_o$ is the density of oil. [2] - Another sphere from the same material but with mass $8m$ released in the oil. Determine the terminal velocity of the new sphere in terms of the terminal velocity of the smaller sphere, $v$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Weight downwards and buoyant force upwards  $\checkmark$
Weight arrow is longer than the buoyant force arrow.  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
