The sphere is accelerating downwards. This is because the gravitational force on the sphere is bigger than the buoyant force. Note that at the instant of release, the is no velocity and therefore no drag force.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0eb89091-7544-4714-b967-648688309f05/images/6b72ec4a-a248-4bff-903d-3f6c8ffa03fc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%204.44.43%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  
- 
  - $mg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$  $\checkmark$ 
Correct steps to reach $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
When the sphere reaches terminal speed, its weight is equal to the sum of the buoyant and drag forces.
    
    
    - $F_g=F_b+F_d$
    - $mg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$
    - $\rho_s Vg=\rho_o Vg+6\pi \eta rv$
    - $v=\dfrac{\rho_s Vg-\rho_o Vg}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{Vg(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{6\pi \eta r}$
    - $v=\dfrac{2r^2 g(\rho_s-\rho_o)}{9\eta}$

    
  - $r_2=2r$  $\checkmark$
$v \propto r^2$  $\checkmark$
$v_2=4v$  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Since the new sphere is from the same material as that in part (b) (i), then:
    
    
    - $\dfrac{m_2}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}$
    - $\dfrac{8m}{V_2} = \dfrac{m}{V}$
    - $V_2=8V$
    - $(r_2)^3=8r^3$
    - $r_2=2r$

    From the relation in (b)(i)
    
    
    - $v \propto r^2$

    Then
    
    
    - $v_2=4v$

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
A firework is dropped from a bridge and explodes a few seconds after release, splitting into three fragments. Which of the following vector diagrams could represent the momenta of the fragments just after the explosion?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12b620d2-a90d-47cc-a5d1-32b2c23b35d4/images/4a7cd6bb-8524-47d1-8c75-92377d277574/image.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12b620d2-a90d-47cc-a5d1-32b2c23b35d4/images/76c65653-a149-4879-9e91-98ed2768bcc0/image.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12b620d2-a90d-47cc-a5d1-32b2c23b35d4/images/3eb12b9b-ab2f-4cbf-ade5-a398c0347f96/image.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12b620d2-a90d-47cc-a5d1-32b2c23b35d4/images/cbd8f9d1-c5ac-4492-b18d-8dd0ae634aaa/image.png)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The total momentum of the firework will increase as it falls towards the Earth, so that the firework will have downwards momentum before the explosion. Due to conservation of momentum, the sum of the momenta of the fragments should therefore also be downwards. In summing the momentum vectors, we are looking for a net momentum towards the Earths surface.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/12b620d2-a90d-47cc-a5d1-32b2c23b35d4/images/effa031c-3bcf-46b9-8837-274552e4e5ba/image.png)


A has a net momentum towards Earth.
B has a net momentum towards Earth and to the right – there cannot be net momentum in the horizontal direction as the is no external force pulling firework horizontally.
C has net momentum away from Earth.
D has net momentum of zero.

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
A ball of mass 100 g hits the ground at an angle of $45\degree$ and a speed of 10 m s$^{-1}$. The collision is elastic, and the ball makes contact with the ground for a total time of 100 ms. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/99fe19b1-7971-4531-bcfc-196700e2ddb3/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.03.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the magnitude of the average net force on the ball during the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $7.1$ N
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $10$ N
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $14$ N
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $20$ N
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}$

The horizontal component of the speed/momentum of the object does not change - the force exerted by ground is purely vertical.
Initial and final vertical velocities are $-10\sin{(45\degree)}$ and +$10\sin{(45\degree)}$ if we take upwards as the positive direction (this will give a positive force as the direction of the force exerted by the ground on the ball is upwards) see diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/67e50acf-d004-4a7b-b955-05573f43c304/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.07.40%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the vertical direction $\Delta v=$ final velocity $-$ initial velocity $=10\sin{45\degree}-(-10\sin{45\degree})=10\sin{45\degree}+10\sin{45\degree}=20\sin{45\degree}$


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{(0.1)(20\sin{45\degree})}{0.1}=20\sin{45\degree}$ = 14 N

(Here we have converted to SI units 100 g = 0.1 kg and 100 ms = 0.1 s)

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
A ball is tied to a $10\,$cm rope and rotates in a horizontal circular path starting from point X with a linear speed of 20 cm s$^{-1}$. The rope is cut after 2 s, at which time the object is at point Y as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/9ffc6634-7ca7-40f1-9f4d-ea886a8b6cf6/PH0638oo.png)



Which of the following is correct about the angular displacement of the ball between $X$ and $Y$ and the direction of motion of the ball after the rope is cut?

Angular DisplacementDirection of Motion$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$2 rad![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/5210521f-2b91-4706-9211-fb6c0774b8cc/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$2 rad![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/3ac33f4a-7f71-4308-8eb1-9661c5e190cb/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.47%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$4 rad![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/fc39ccb2-72d4-4f75-8e6e-83e5be9cc95f/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.53.55%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$4 rad![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/270e4c90-9a2f-4eb0-9f73-d5b8c6206f04/images/696bb73f-ee37-47b5-8949-d432806f9ae9/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.54.07%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Note that although the direction is not stated in the question, from determining the angular displacement, the direction it is traveling can be determined.
$\hspace{1em}$ $\omega=\dfrac{v}{r}$
$\hspace{1em}$ $\omega=\dfrac{20}{10}=$ 2 rad s$^{-1}$
$\hspace{1em}$ $\omega =\dfrac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}$
$\hspace{1em}$ $\Delta \theta = \omega \Delta t = (2)(2) = 4$ rad
Because one full circle is $2 \pi$ radians, we can see that $\Delta \theta$ is approximately $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of a full circle. Therefore, it must be moving clockwise around the circle. This allows us to determine that the tangential velocity at that point in time must be up and to the right.

list.title: Question 53
list.content:
An airplane of weight $W$ is flying horizontally with constant velocity. The total forward thrust of the engines is $3W$. Which of the following gives the magnitude of the force of the air on the plane?


- A. $\hspace{1em} 4W$
- B. $\hspace{1em} 3W$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{10}W$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{8} W$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to the absence of acceleration, the resultant force must be zero. Therefore, both the forward thrust and the weight must be cancelled by forces from the air.
The force from the air has two components; $3\, W$ in backward drag and $W$ in upward lift.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3007ef36-6df7-4d85-8b06-cbef0a761c62/images/4c76b22c-495d-4463-b7dc-a89c63d18c53/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.59.56%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Using Pythagoras' theorem to find the resultant of these two components:


- R = $\sqrt{(3W)^2+ W^2 } = \sqrt{10}\,  W$

list.title: Question 54
list.content: While practising, a table tennis player hits a ball of mass 2.8 g that collides with the floor and then bounces back from the wall. The speed of the ball just before reaching the floor is 8.0 m s$^{-1}$. The ball leaves the floor with an angle of 65$\degree$ to the floor as shown. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f046049-9d52-4f31-bdb9-04593858342e/images/33f83956-3349-49c0-b000-e177f8854ee9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.39.45%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Due to the collision with the floor, the ball losses 30$\%$ of its initial kinetic energy. Show that the leaving speed of the ball from the floor is around 7 m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The ball strikes the wall just as it reaches the highest point of its motion. Determine the horizontal distance between the bounce point and the wall. [3] - The ball collides elastically with the wall, with the time of contact during the collision is 0.040 s. Calculate the average horizontal force exerted by the wall on the ball during the collision. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\textrm{Initial\ Kinetic\ Energy}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v= \sqrt{\dfrac{(0.7)(.090\ )(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=\answer{6.7\ \ce{m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The kinetic energy $E_{ki}$ just before the collision; $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2$  where $u$ is the speed of the ball just before the collision
  
  
  - $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J

  Since 30$\%$ of the $E_{ki}$ is lost, the final kinetic energy $E_{Kf}$ is
  
  
  - $E_{kf}=\left(0.7\right)\left(0.090\right)=0.063$ J
  - $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$,  where $v$ is the speed of the ball just after the collision
  - $0.063=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({v)}^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(0.063)(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=6.7$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- Vertically,
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ $\checkmark$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0\ -\ 6.7\sin({65\degree})}{9.8}\ = \ 0.62$ s $\checkmark$

  Horizontally,
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos({65\degree})\left(0.62\right)=\answer{1.8\ \ce{m}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The ball undergoes projectile motion. The collision with the wall takes place when the ball is at the highest part of its motion, so the vertical component of the motion can be used to find the time of flight.
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ and $y = 0$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0-6.7\sin\left({65\degree}\right)}{9.8}\  =\ 0.62$ s

  Using this time in the horizontal direction, where $u_x = 6.7\cos(65\degree)$
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos\left({65\degree}\right)\left(0.62\right)=1.8$ m




- $\Delta p = 2mv = 2(0.0028)(6.7\cos(65\degree)) =0.016$ N s $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $F\ =\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}= \dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= \answer{0.40\ \ce{N}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
As the ball rebounds elastically, the final speed is equal to the initial speed.
  These speeds are equal to the horizontal component of the velocity
  
  
  - $v_x=6.7\cos(65\degree) =2.83$ m s$^{-1}$

  To find change in momentum
  $\begin{aligned}
   \Delta p&=p_2-p_1 \\
   &=mv_2-mv_1 \\
   &=0.0028\left(2.83-\left(-2.83\right)\right)
   =0.016\textrm{ N s}
   \end{aligned}$
  Note that because of the change in direction, the change in momentum is equal to twice the initial momentum.
  To find force,
  
  
  
  - $F\ =\ \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= 0.40$ N

list.title: Question 55
list.content: A roller coaster car with a mass of 80 kg moves on the track shown in the diagram starting from point A. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/8e2a2b25-a38d-4443-889f-8825dd14b886/PH1005_a.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https:// pixabay.com]}}$ At points B and C, the track approximates a circular path so that the radii at at B and C are 12 m and 18 m respectively. - Compare the normal force exerted by the track on the car at points B and C. [2] - Draw and label the free body diagram of the car at point C. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/ea0213e1-1751-4828-b183-089d74c0f60a/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.08.24%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Calculate the maximum speed of the car at point C so that it could remain on the track. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $N_B=\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}+mg$ AND $N_C=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}$ $\checkmark$
  The normal force at B is greater than the normal force at C. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
  Resolving the forces at B
  
  
  - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}=N_B-mg$
  - $N_B=mg +\dfrac{mv^2}{r_B}$

  While at C,
  
  
  - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}=mg-N_C$
  - $N_C=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_C}$

  The normal force at B is greater than the normal force at C.



- 
  - .
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6f8b40cd-a38f-4e89-a840-e407d2693c6d/images/a06209b9-e955-4a18-9e31-0075792f4caa/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.11.27%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    Upward normal force AND downward gravitational force. $\checkmark$
    The downward arrow is bigger than the upward arrow. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Because the car is at the top of a curve, the centripetal accleration must be towards the centre which is in the downwards direction. The accleration must also therefore be downwards, so the gravitational force must be greater than the upwards normal force.
    
  - The maximum speed is when the normal force is zero. $\checkmark$
    $v=\ll\sqrt{r_cg}\gg=\sqrt{\left(18\right)(9.81)}$ $\checkmark$
    $v=\answer{13\  \textrm{m s}^{-1}}\ \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    The maximum speed at point C is when the normal force of the track on the car is zero.
    The normal force at C
    
    
    - $F_N=mg-\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}$

    When $F_N = 0$
    
    
    - $mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r_c}$

    Using the given value of $r=18$ m
    
    
    - $v=\sqrt{r_cg}=\sqrt{(18)(9.81)}=13.29\textrm{ m s}^{-1}$

list.title: Question 56
list.content: - - A spacecraft is moving in a zero gravity zone in space with constant speed. Its pilot decided to accelerate by burning fuel. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of $2.5\times{10}^2$ m s$^{-1}$ relative to the rocket at a constant rate of $2.0\times{10}^2$ kg s$^{-1}$. Show that the net force on the rocket due to the ejection of burnt fuel is $5 \times 10^4$ N. [1] - The spacecraft has a mass of $4.2\times{10}^3$ kg at the instant that it starts to burn the fuel. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft after $1.0$ s has passed. [2] - The spacecraft enters the atmosphere of Mars and slows down due to friction. To decelerate its speed more to reach a safe landing speed, the operator runs a propeller that pushes against the gas in the atmosphere. - By referring to Newton's Third Law, outline why there is a force acting on the spacecraft due to the propeller. [2] - The average density of the Mars atmosphere is $0.020$ kg m$^{-3}$. The radius of the propeller blades is $1.2$ m. At a given instant, the average force from the propeller to slow down the spacecraft is $1.4$ kN. Assuming that the propeller causes all gas that it passes through to come to rest relative to the falling spaceship, estimate the speed of the spaceship at this instant. [4] - The landing legs of the spacecraft have springs that can compress as the spacecraft makes contact with the ground. Explain how this decreases the average force acting on the spacecraft as it lands. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v = (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) = \answer{5.0 \times 10^4}$ << N >>$\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
From Newton's 3rd Law, the force of the rocket on the gases is equal to the force of the gases on the rocket.
    For the gases, the net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum.
    Substituting in the values will lead the net force
    $\begin{aligned}
     F&=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t}\\
      &= \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v \\
      &= (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) \\
      &= 5.0 \times 10^4\textrm{ N}\\
      \end{aligned}$

  
  
  - Mass of the rocket at $t=1$ s is
    
    
    - $4200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^3$ kg $\checkmark$
    - $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3} = $ $12.5$ m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The total mass $m_t$ of the rocket after $1$ s:
    
    
    - $m_t=4200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\times\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^3$ kg

    To find the acceleration of the rocket:
    
    
    - $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3}=12.5$ m s$^{-2}$

    

- 
  - Propellor exerts a force on the gas $\checkmark$
    There is an equal and opposite force from the gas on the propeller $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gas in the atmosphere experiences a force due to the propeller blades. According to Newton's Third Law, a force with the same magnitude and opposite direction acts on the spacecraft.
    
  - $F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}{} = m\dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\, \checkmark$
    $m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt \, \checkmark$
    $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}\ \, \checkmark$
    = $120$ m s$^{-1}$ $\, \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The distance $l$ covered by the spacetime in a short time of $t$:
    $l=vt$   where $v$ is the average speed of the spacecraft
    The mass $m$ of the gas pushed during the time of $t$:
    $m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt$ where $r$ is the radius of the blades
    The mass experiences a change of velocity of $v$, as relative to the aircraft it is initially moving at speed $v$ and comes to rest due to the propellors
    The average force $F_{av}$ needed from the propeller;
    $\begin{aligned}
     F_{av}&=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &= \dfrac{\rhoπr^2vt\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &=\rhoπr^2v^2\\
     \end{aligned}$
    Rearranging gives
    $\hspace{1.12cm}v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.4\times{10}^3}{(0.020)\pi{(1.2)}^2}}=120$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - $\Delta p=F_{av}\Delta t$   $\, \checkmark$
    duration of the collison is increased $\, \checkmark$
    Change in momentum is the same so the average force is less $\, \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The time of collision is increased with using soft material.  By using Newton’s second law;
    
    
    - $F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}$

    For the same magnitude of the change in momentum, the average force acting on the object is less when the time of collision is increased.

list.title: Question 57
list.content: - Define momentum. [1] - A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s$^{-1}$ undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/a31f1159-d99f-4baa-a497-a3dd8fb09c8a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision. [3] - The variation of force acting on the golf ball $F$ with the time $t$ during the collision is shown in the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/56c450d9-aa69-4205-b5b8-66efcaaa540a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.05.14%E2%80%AFPM.png) Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$. [2] - Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision. [3] - Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The product of mass and velocity. $\checkmark$



- 
  - According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/$F_g=-F_s$ $\checkmark$
    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/$\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$ $\checkmark$
    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ since $\Delta t$ for each ball is equal, $\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_s$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ball $F_g$ equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball $F_s$ during the collision.
    
    
    - $F_g=-F_s$

    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}$   equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$.
    
    
    - $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$

    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.
    
  - Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum $\checkmark$
    change in momentum = $\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$ (extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangle $A_t$ should be calculated to get the change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    $\begin{aligned}
     \Delta p &= A_t\\
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
      &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - Use of $\Delta p=mv-mu$ $\checkmark$
    $-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)$ $\checkmark$ (negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)
    $v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$
    Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$ gives a final speed of 0 m s$^{-1}$. This is accepted if full working is shown.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=-0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=45\times10^{-3}$ kg, $u=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$, and $v=$ final velocity after the collision.
    $\begin{aligned}
     -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
     \end{aligned}$
    
  - Kinetic energy before the collision = $\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
    Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N s
    
    
    - $p = mv$
    - $0.086=2.0v$

    Speed of the stationary ball after the collision $=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)
    
    
    - $E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020$ J
    - $0.0020$ J $\checkmark$

    Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic. $\checkmark$
    Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collision $E_{tkb}$ equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collision $E_{kgb}$;
    
    
    - $E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J

    The speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found by
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=2.0$ kg, $u=0$ m s$^{-1}$
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
       \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
       \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
       \end{aligned}$

    The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collision $E_{tka}$ equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golf $E_{kga}$ and stationary balls $E_{ksa}$ after the collision;
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
       &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
       &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
       &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
       \end{aligned}$

    $E_{tkb}>E_{tka}$, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

list.title: Question 58
list.content:
A mass $m$ is moving on a circular path at the end of a rope of constant length. The centripetal force acting on the mass is $F$.
The frequency of the motion is gradually increased.
Which graph correctly shows the change of the centripetal force $F_c$ as the frequency $f$ is increased?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/775fbf10-3bc4-4ebe-b512-ff6082e1e19e/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.18%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/5cdacb61-797f-46e1-8f53-056da57c9dda/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.23%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/08449c73-c15e-47dc-ac1c-b31237189261/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.28%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/630ba233-a848-4273-b0a6-76a57dfee62b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In the data booklet, given centripetal acceleration:


- $a=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}$

which can also be expressed as


- $a=4\pi^2rf^2$

Since $F=ma$,


- $F=m4\pi^2rf^2$

Therefore the graph of $F$ vs $f$ must be a quadratic as in A.

list.title: Question 59
list.content: The motion of an object released from a high place in a vacuum is observed. The variation of its velocity $v$ with time $t$ is recorded and the following graph is obtained. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb3f57e7-c203-4906-83ba-9e90bed837aa/images/93def1d0-85b3-48b2-91f2-60218dac0567/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.27.44%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - Discuss the role that observations play in the development of scientific understanding. [1] - Other than velocity and time, list two quantities that can be obtained from the graph. [2] - - The height of the release point is $70$ m. Show that the speed $v_1$ of the object just before the contact with the ground is $37$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The object rebounds from the ground with a speed $v_2$ of $17$ m s$^{-1}$. The mass of the object is $8.0$ kg and the contact time during the rebound is $0.50$ s. Calculate the average force acting on the object from the ground. [4]
list.markScheme:
- They lead to the development of theories $\checkmark$
  
  
  - OR

  They are used to construct or test a hypothesis $\checkmark$
  
  
  - OR

  They are used to construct a mathematical relationship $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Observations are fundamental for many parts of physics. They help to understand the behaviour of nature. According to observations, mathematical relationships can be obtained, a hypothesis can be constructed or tested and new theories can be developed.
  
- acceleration $\checkmark$
  displacement/distance $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The slope of the velocity-time graph is equal to acceleration and the area under the graph gives the displacement. Since the motion happens in one dimension and one direction, the magnitude of displacement and distance are the same. The distance can be also obtained.
  
- 
  - ${v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)$ $\checkmark$
Accept using other uniform acceleration equations
    ${\ll v}_1=\gg$37.06$\ \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The object falls with an acceleration of $-9.81$ m s$^{-2}$ and it is released from rest. The speed of the object can be found from
    
    
    - $v^2=u^2+2as$

    where $u=0$ and $s=-70$ m
    
    
    - ${v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)$
    - ${v_1}^2=0+(2)(-9.81)(-70)$
    - $v_1=37.06$ m s$^{-1}$

    
  - $p_{before} = 296$ kg m$s^{-1}$ and $p_{after}=136$ kg m s$^{-1}$  $\checkmark$
    $\Delta p =mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432$ kg m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    $F_{net} = \dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864$ N $\checkmark$
    $F_N \ll = F_{net}+mg=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\gg=$ 942 N $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The momentum of the object before the collision with the ground
    
    
    - $p_{before}=mv_1=\left(8\right)\left(-37\right)=\ -296$ kg m s$^{-1}$

    The momentum of the object after the collision with the ground
    
    
    - $p_{after}=mv_2=\left(8\right)\left(17\right)=136$ kg m s$^{-1}$

    Change in momentum $\Delta p$ of the object
    
    
    - $\Delta p=mv_2-\ mv_1=136-\left(-296\right)=432$ kg m s$^{-1}$

    The resultant force $F_{net}$ acting on the object during the  rebound
    
    
    - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}\ =\ \dfrac{432}{0.50}\ =\ 864$ N

    During the collision, two forces act on the object: contact and weight. They are in opposite directions. Therefore, the resultant force $F_{net}$;
    $\begin{aligned}
     F_{net} &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
     F_N-W &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
     F_N-mg &= 864\textrm{ N} \\
     F_N-\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right) &=864\textrm{ N}\\
     F_N\ &=864+\left(8\right)\left(9.81\right)\\
     F_N\ &=942\textrm{ N}\\
     \end{aligned}$
    Note that the force from the ground accomplishes two things here: it exerts a net force on the ball that causes its change in momentum and it also counteracts the force of gravity that acts downwards on the ball.

list.title: Question 60
list.content:
During a game of pool, a cue ball traveling at a velocity $v$ collides with a stationary ball. After the collision each of the balls move at 45 degrees to the initial velocity of the cue ball as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4e45fdf3-ab76-456e-a437-96f212df97cb/images/173e20c4-e008-4a67-934a-ffae87cc8b5f/Screenshot%202025-02-26%20at%209.21.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The mass of each of the balls is $m$. What is the impulse experienced by either of the balls in the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{mv}{2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt{2}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $mv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to symmetry, the final velocities $V$ of the balls will be the same. We can see this as the masses are the same and the magnitude of the vertical components of the velocity must be the same due to conservation of vertical momentum.
Impulse ($J$) is equal to change in momentum. The simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.


- $J=m\Delta v$

We can find the horizontal component of this velocity $V_H$ using conservation of momentum. Setting the horizontal momentum before the collision equal to the horizontal momentum after the collision:


- $mv+0=mV_H+mV_H$
- $mv=2mV_H$
- $V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}$

After the collision, the balls move at 45° (so the vector triangle is isosceles) so the magnitude of the vertical component of the balls' final velocity is equal to the horizontal component


- $V_V=V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}$.

Now $V$ is the vector sum of $V_H$ and $V_V$, which can be calculated using Pythagoras' theorem:


- $V=\sqrt{V_H^2+V_V^2}=\sqrt{\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2+\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2}=\sqrt{\dfrac{v^2}{2}}=\dfrac{v}{\sqrt{2}}$

Because the ball was initally stationary, this also represents the change in velocity of the ball. The impulse of the collision is therefore:


- $I=mV=\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt2}$

list.title: Question 61
list.content:
A roller coaster car of mass $m$ approximates circular motion at point $A$ as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/10007213-04cb-4d62-9b1c-88f2b14aaab5/images/8e8ebb9e-4b0d-4aa0-a92a-3b7d7d42fb2c/PH0637.png)


The circular radius of the track curvature at point $A$ is $r$ and the track exerts a normal reaction force $F_N$ on the cart.
Which expression gives the linear speed of the cart at point $A$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{2rg}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{r(F_N-mg)}{m}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The centripetal force at point $A$ is the vector sum of the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force of the track
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_{centripetal}=mg-F_N$
And
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_{centripetal}=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$
Then
$\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg-F_N$
$\hspace{2em}$ $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{r(mg-F_N)}{m}}$

list.title: Question 62
list.content:
A ball of mass $0.1$ kg moves horizontally with a speed $5.0$ m s$^{-1}$, hits a vertical wall and rebounds with speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$. The graph records the variation of force $F$ with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2bff193b-02d9-474c-b49d-26f0cde018f1/images/50add01d-d355-4459-8f2d-02deb046cc73/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.31.17%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


What is $F_{max}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 4 N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 8 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 40 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 80 N
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For a force time graph; the area under the graph is equal to the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball.
The change in momentum; $\Delta p$


- $\Delta p = m(v-u)=0.1(-3-5)=-0.8$ kg m s$^{-1}$

The area under the graph = magnitude of change in momentum


- $\dfrac{1}{2}(20 \times 10^{-3})(F_{max}) = 0.8$
- $F_{max} = \dfrac{(0.8)(2)}{(20 \times 10^{-3})}=80$ N

list.title: Question 63
list.content:
An inclined plane makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. An object with mass $m$ is just about to slide on the inclined plane.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/950558eb-10e3-4013-a94c-8b1d59c57e6f/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.28.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Which of the following is correct about the coefficient of static friction $\mu_s$ and the free body diagram of the mass?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\mu_s$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$Free body diagram $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sin \theta$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/5461c876-eaca-4f84-ba61-62a0bbcfaef4/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.30.37%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sin \theta$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/65c85e1f-85f5-460c-9d65-fda3ae36e79a/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.30.19%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\tan \theta$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/0ab9e045-5c8f-4c2a-a71a-56c1b40c1548/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.30.37%E2%80%AF1PM.png)

$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\tan \theta$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/683be975-25cf-47e4-8661-84f0de2d45c3/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.30.191%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The free body diagram of the object. Note that there is no force pointing down the slope. It is a component of weight ($mg$) that acts down the slope.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/327df27b-8743-40de-a4f0-2c7f8be50f6f/images/eb0a8a69-9f1e-4c09-9659-f48ebc327f9e/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.28.53%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Since the object is just about to slide, then


- $N=mg\cos\theta$

And


- $F_f=mg\sin\theta$

The static friction force is given by


- $F_f=\mu_sF_N=\mu_smg\cos\theta$

Then


- $mg\sin\theta = \mu_smg\cos\theta$
- $\mu_s=\dfrac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} $
- $\mu_s=\tan\theta $

list.title: Question 64
list.content:
A block of mass 4.0 kg rests on an inclined plane.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/a2d8fdc5-6a82-406e-a19b-9649d2967b5c/PH0330.png)


The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane $\mu _s$ is 0.4.
Which of the following gives the angle of inclination at which the block will start to slide?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sin^{-1}(0.4)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.4)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\cos^{-1}(0.4)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.6)$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/1ea450be-a2a5-44f8-aca9-38d06abc4237/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.09.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)




- $F_N = mg\cos\theta$
- $F = \mu_sF_N$
- $F = mg\sin\theta$
- $mg(\sin\theta) = 0.4mg(\cos\theta$)
- $\dfrac{\sin\theta } {\cos\theta}=0.4$
- $\tan\theta = 0.4$
- $\theta=\tan^{-1}(0.4)$

list.title: Question 65
list.content:
Two objects of mass $M$ and $m$ are connected via a frictionless pulley. The rope attached to the object of mass $M$ makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. The objects are at rest.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a39026f-aa75-494c-a20c-39635e9e1fc0/images/155ede1a-26a4-4810-8047-d312bfef3356/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.43.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of friction F$_f$  and the normal force F$_N$?

$\hspace{3em}$ F$_f$ $\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{4em}$ F$_N$ $\hspace{4em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Resolving vertical forces on the large block:


- $F_g = F_N + T\sin \theta$

And for the large block,


- $F_g = Mg$

Substituting and solving for $F_N$ gives


- $F_N =  Mg - T\sin \theta$

Resolving horizontal forces on the large block:


- $F_f = T \cos \theta$

For the vertical forces small block


- $T = mg$

Substituting gives $F_f = mg \cos \theta$

list.title: Question 66
list.content:
Below are three suggested units for viscocity


- I.kg m$^{-1}$ s$^{-1}$II.Pa sIII.N s m$^{-1}$

Which of the unit combinations is/are correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Drag:


- $F_d=6\pi \eta rv$

By making viscosity the subject of the formula:


- $\eta =\dfrac{F_d}{6\pi rv}$

Units are substituted:


- $\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m})(\textrm{m s}^{-1})}=\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{(\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1})}=\textrm{ N s m}^{-2}$

By replacing N m$^{-2}$ = Pa:


- N s m$^{-2}$ = Pa s

By replacing N = kg m s$^{-2}$:


- $\dfrac{\textrm{N}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\dfrac{\textrm{kg m s}^{-2}}{\textrm{m}^2\textrm{ s}^{-1}}=\textrm{kg m}^{-1}\textrm{ s}^{-1}$

list.title: Question 67
list.content:
A point $P$ is subjected to three simultaneous forces of magnitudes $F_A > F_B > F_C$. Point $P$ is in equilibrium. Consider of the following statements.


- I.$F_A = F_B + F_C$II.$F_A \leq F_B + F_C$III.$F_A > F_B - F_C$

Which of the statements is not always true about the magnitudes of the forces?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Vectors of forces in equilibrium form a triangle or a straight line.
The sum of two sides of a triangle is always greater than the third (II is always true).
The difference between two sides of a triangle is always less than the third (III is also always true).
I is true only when the three forces are in a straight line and $F_B$ and $F_C$ are both opposing $F_A$(not always true, as required by the question).

list.title: Question 68
list.content:
A toy of mass $m$ is attached to a rod of length $L$ and undergoes circular motion in the vertical plane. The radial force $F$ of the rod is constant.
What is the ratio of the linear speed at the top to the linear speed at the bottom of its path, $\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
At the top, the centripetal force is $F+mg=\dfrac{m(v_{top})^2}{r}$
At the bottom, the centripetal force is $F-mg=\dfrac{m(v_{bottom})^2}{r}$
Rearranging the above equations for the required ratio gives:
$\hspace{3em}$ $\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}$

list.title: Question 69
list.content: - A small solid sphere is released from rest at the surface of a container of water. The initial position of the sphere is illustrated below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/2beb822d-1d48-498e-b519-356d294d1cc0/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%201.50.24%E2%80%AFPM.png) The graph below shows how the velocity of the sphere $v$ varies with time $t$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/22828803-90f8-43db-a282-e36f99ed9c3a/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%201.57.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) Explain the shape of the graph. [3] - - The radius of the sphere is 0.61 mm and the viscosity of the water is $1.0\times 10^{-3}$ Pa s. Show that the maximum drag force acting on the sphere is around $5\times 10^{-6}$ N. [2] - It is given that the total denisty of the sphere is 50% greater than that of water. Calculate the weight of the sphere. [3] - After 0.8 seconds the sphere reaches the bottom of the container and comes to rest instantaneously. Use the graph to estimate the depth of water in the container. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Initially there is a net force downwards / initial forces are weight (downwards) and buoyancy (upwards) and weight is greater than buoyancy, so the sphere accelerates downwards.  $\checkmark$
  Downwards acceleration decreases due to drag/friction/viscous drag.  $\checkmark$
  Terminal speed is reached / sphere reaches a constant speed when $W=F_b+F_d$ (Weight = Drag + Buoyancy)  $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Initially (when $v=0$) the only forces acting on the sphere are weight $W$ and buoyancy $F_b$. The free body diagram is as follows:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/4f083578-cfd2-4ecd-bb1b-6ed9c5426ca9/image.png)


  $W$ is greater than $F_b$ causing the sphere to accelerate downwards.
  As the velocity $v$ increases, drag force $F_d$ increases opposing the direction of the motion. When $F_b$ has increased to the point where the forces are balanced $W=F_b+F_d$. The free body diagram is as follows:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a304d32-6cfd-4a78-9edc-a475513e097f/images/2c4e2a33-21fc-44de-a55c-e55f3786d7c8/image.png)


  Now the sphere is in equilibrium so will remain at a constant velocity (terminal speed).
  
- 
  - 
    
    - $F_d=6\pi \eta rv$ and $v=0.4$ m s$^{-1}$  $\checkmark$
    - $F_d=6\pi (1.0\times 10^{-3})(0.61\times10^{-3})(0.4)= $ $4.6\times 10^{-6}\textrm{ N}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Drag force is maximum when the sphere reaches its terminal speed. We can see form the graph that velocity plateaus at $0.4$ m s$^{-1}$. Hence terminal speed is $0.4$ m s$^{-1}$.
    The equation for viscous drag for small spherical objects is $F_d=6\pi \eta rv$
    Substituting our values:
    
    
    - Viscosity $\eta =1.0\times 10^{-3}$ Pa s
    - Radius $r=0.61\times 10^{-3}$ m
    - Terminal speed $v=0.4$ m s$^{-1}$
    - $F_d=6\pi(1.0\times 10^{-3})(0.61\times 10^{-3})(0.4)=4.6\times 10^{-6}$ N

    
  - Weight is 50% greater than buoyancy / $W=1.5F_b$ / $F_b=\dfrac{2}{3}\,W$  $\checkmark$
    Deducing that
$\dfrac{W}{3}=F_d$ / $W=3F_d$  $\checkmark$
    $W=(3)(4.6\times 10^{-6})=14\times 10^{-6}\textrm{ N}=\answer{1.4\times 10^{-5}\textrm{ N}}$    $\checkmark$
    (Note: Use of $F_d=5\times 10^{-6}$ gives $1.5\times10^{-5}\textrm{ N})$
    $\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}$:
    Density of water $= 1.0\times 10^3$ kg m$^{-1}$
    Density if sphere $= 1.5\times 10^3$ kg m$^{-1}$  $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $W=\rho Vg $

    And
    
    
    - $V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$  $\checkmark$
    - $W=(\rho)\Bigl(\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3\Bigr)g=(1.5\times 10^3)\Bigl(\dfrac{4}{3} \pi (0.61\times 10^3)^3\Bigr)(9.81)=\answer{1.4\times 10^{-5}\textrm{ N}}$  $\checkmark$

    Award full marks for correct answer.
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Let ${\rho}_{sphere}$ and ${\rho}_{water}$ be the respective densities of the sphere and the water and $V$ be the volume of the sphere.
    We know that ${\rho}_{sphere}=1.5{\rho}_{water}$
    Weight: $W=m_{sphere}g={\rho}_{sphere}Vg=1.5{\rho}_{water}Vg$
    Buoyancy: $F_b={\rho}_{water} Vg$
    So, we may write:
    
    
    - $\dfrac{W}{F_b} =\dfrac{1.5{\rho}_{water}Vg}{{\rho}_{water} Vg}=1.5  $
    - $F_b=\dfrac{2}{3} W $

    At terminal speed $W=F_b+F_d$
    Substituting $F_b=\dfrac{2}{3} W$ gives:
    
    
    - $W=\dfrac{2}{3} W+F_d$
    - $\dfrac{W}{3}=F_d $
    - $W=3F_d $
    - $W=(3)(4.6\times 10^{-6})=14\times 10^{-5}\,N=1.4\times 10^{-3}\textrm{ N}$

    

- Evidence of using area under graph
  e.g., “Depth = Area under graph” or “large square $=0.01$ m”  $\checkmark$
  Depth 0.27 m $\checkmark$
  Allow answers in range 0.25 m - 0.29 m
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
Displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph.
  The displacement covered by the sphere in $0.8$ s is the depth of water in the container.
  Each large square has an area of (0.1 s)(0.1 m s$^{-1})=$0.01 m.
  There are around 27 large squares between the curve and the lines $t=0$ and $t=0.8$.
  So, area $=(27)(0.01)=0.27$ m = depth.

list.title: Question 70
list.content: A car enters a horizontal circular roundabout as shown with a speed of 35 km h$^{-1}$. The radius of the roundabout is 15 m. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae5d5d2c-d886-4aa8-875e-97c202da73d1/images/678c565e-beaf-419e-8ae6-5608f15c2ecf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.32.11%E2%80%AFPM.png) - State the force which provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the car. [1] - Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction between the tyres of the car and the road for the car to safely complete its motion around the roundabout. [3] - State and explain any change in your answer to part (b) if: - The mass of the car increases. [2] - The road is banked at an angle so that the car is tilted towards the center of the roundabout. [2] - The speed of the car increases. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Frictional force (between the road and the car tyres) $\checkmark$
  Weight is not accepted as a response here.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
It is the force of friction between the road and the tires that provides the force towards the centre of the roundabout. Without friction, the car would not be able to make the turn.
  
- The speed of the car is ($35\textrm{ km h}^{-1}$, which is $\dfrac{35000\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}})=$ 9.72 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  Frictional force provides the centripetal force, therefore $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\mu$
  Rearranging gives $\mu=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}$ $\checkmark$
  OR
  The substitution: $\mu=\dfrac{9.72^2}{(15)(9.8)}$ = 0.64 $\checkmark$
  (2 marks max if speed is not converted to m s$^{-1}$. This gives 8.33)
  
- 
  - No change $\checkmark$
    The mass of the car impacts the calculation of the frictional force and centripetal force equally/cancels in the calculation. $\checkmark$
    
  - Decrease $\checkmark$
    The normal force would contribute to the centripetal force, therefore less frictional force would be sufficient. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
On a banked turn, the normal force will have a component that points towards the centre of the circle. As the centripetal force required is the same as on a non-banked turn, less frictional force is required and therefore a lower coefficient of friction is sufficient.
    
  - Increase $\checkmark$
    At a higher speed, a larger centripetal force would be necessary to maintain the circular motion. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
A higher speed will increase the value of $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$, resulting in the need for a higher value for the coefficient of friction $\mu$.

list.title: Question 71
list.content: A box half filled with sand is pulled by a motor at a constant speed of $2.0$ m s$^{-1}$ on a frictionless surface. During the motion, sand is added to the box from above at a constant rate of $\sigma$ kg s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e91a12f8-310f-42b8-a135-30c0ad0e892e/images/fb1ec50a-d277-4d69-95d5-266cdd06f303/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.45.240%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State the condition related to the mass of an object in order for the equation $F_{net}=ma$ to be equivalent to the equation $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}$ . [1] - The force applied by the motor on the box is $0.11$ N. Determine $\sigma$. [2] - The motor has an efficiency of 75%. Calculate the total power provided to the motor. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Mass of the object should be constant $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum
  
  
  - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

  Therefore $F_{net}$ can depend on the rate of change of mass or the rate of change of velocity or both.
  The equation
  
  
  - $F=ma$

  is equivalent to
  
  
  - $F=m\dfrac{\Delta v}{t}$

  and therefore assumes that mass is constant and that only velocity is changing with time.
  
- 
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ $\checkmark$
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}= $ $0.055\textrm{ kg s}^{-1}$  $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force $F$ applied to the box;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$

  Since $v$ is constant;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}$

  When $\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$ is replaced with $\sigma$;
  
  
  - $F=v\sigma$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ where $F=0.11$ N and $v=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$

  
  
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055$ kg s$^{-1}$




- Useful power output of the motor $=\ll Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=\gg 0.22$ W $\checkmark$
  The power provided to the motor $=\ll \dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = \gg $  0.29 W $ \checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The useful power output $P_o$ of the motor;
  
  
  - $P_o=Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=0.22$ W

  The efficiency of the motor;
  
  
  - Efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Input power}} \times 100\%$

  So the input power;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Efficiency}} \times 100\%$

  Substitute the given and calculated values;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = 0.29\,W$

list.title: Question 72
list.content:
Two bodies of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are connected by a thread and pulled in the upward direction with an acceleration of $g$ due to an upward force $F$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb9106b9-d99e-4523-b2e9-efa16a2c17a6/images/cbe0daf4-7e77-4429-a129-869ae3fb9bb1/PH0245q.JPEG)


The thread between the masses is cut. Which of the following is correct for the bodies just after the cut?

Acceleration of 3 kg massAcceleration of 2 kg mass$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $4g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $4g$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F = ma$

Before the thread is cut,


- $F - W = ma$  for the system
- $W = mg = 5g    $ and  $\ ma=5g$

Therefore


- $F = 5g + 5g = 10g$

Just after the cut, the 3 kg mass is only under the influence of gravity, so its accleration is equal to $g$
The net force on the 2 kg mass is


- $F - 2g = 10g - 2g= 8g $

Acceleration of the 3 kg mass = $g$
Acceleration of 2 kg mass = $ \dfrac{8g}{2} = 4g$

list.title: Question 73
list.content:
An object of mass $m$ and initial velocity $v$ collides with a stationary object of mass $2m$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f1971e54-30eb-442a-aa50-607973aad940/images/3fb732f1-87a9-449f-b833-c4c911243712/Screenshot%202025-03-25%20at%207.24.54%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


After the collision the object of mass $2m$ moves with velocity $\dfrac{2v}{3}$.  What is the final velocity of the object of mass $m$ and the magnitude of impulse of the collision?

$\textrm{Final velocity of mass}$ $m$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\textrm{Impulse}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{-v}{3}$ $\dfrac{2mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{-v}{3}$ $\dfrac{4mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$ $\dfrac{2mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$ $\dfrac{4mv}{3}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using conservation of momentum, we set the initial momentum equal of the system equal to the final momentum. We can represent the final velocity of the object of mass $m$ as $v_{fm}$. Applying the law of conservation of momentum gives


- $mv=mv_{fm}+2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)$
- $v=v_{fm}+2\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)$
- $v_{fm}=v-\dfrac{4v}{3}=\dfrac{-v}{3}$

The negative sign represents the fact that the smaller mass will bounce backwards in the collision.
Impulse $J$ is equal to change in momentum.


- $J=m\Delta v$

The simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.


- $J=m\Delta v=2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}-0\right)=\dfrac{4mv}{3}$

list.title: Question 74
list.content:
A spherical raindrop falls at a terminal speed of $v$. Its density is $\rho$ and its radius is $r$ Which of the following expressions is correct for $v$? (Buoyancy acting on the raindrop is insignificant)


- A. $\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  		v=\dfrac{2g\rho r}{3\eta}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{24\pi^2g\eta\rho r^4}{3}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	v=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{3\eta}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The mass $m$ of the raindrop can be expressed as


- $m=\rho V=\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$

When the weight of the raindrop is balanced with the drag force, it falls at a constant speed:


- $mg=6\pi\eta rv$

When $m$ is replaced with the expression above:


- $\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g=6\pi\eta rv$

Solving for $v$ gives


- $v=\dfrac{\rho\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3g}{6\pi\eta r}=\dfrac{2g\rho r^2}{9\eta}$

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
A spherical object of radius $r$ is released from rest inside a fluid, after some time it reaches a terminal velocity $v$. The density of the fluid is $\rho_f$ and the density of the object is negligible compared to $\rho_f$. Which of the following is a correct expression for the viscosity of the fluid?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3g}{9v}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2gv}{9}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3gv}{9}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Because of the very low density of the object, in this situation it will be rising upwards through the fluid and the drag force will be directed downwards. The forces acting on the object are represented in the diagram below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fd1b8088-49d6-4cf0-a32e-2f667b767317/images/54c6d222-8e3b-49ea-a0d9-c1152711872e/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.35.15%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Weight is negligible due to the negligible object density.


- $\rho_{\textrm{object}}\ll\rho_f$
- $(\textrm{weight}=\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg\ll\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg=\textrm{buoyancy})$

When the object is at terminal velocity the net force acting on it is zero so we have:


- $\textrm{weight}=\textrm{drag force}$

Where:


- Buoyancy $=\rho_fVg$
- Drag $=6\pi\eta rv$

Where $g$ is acceleration due to gravity, $V$ is the volume of the ball, and $\eta$ is the viscosity of the liquid.


- $\rho_fVg=6\pi\eta rv$

Now substituting the volume of a sphere $V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$ and rearranging for $\eta$ we have:


- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^3g=6\pi\eta rv$
- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^2g=6\eta v$
- $\eta=\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$

list.title: Question 76
list.content:
A stationary object explodes and splits into two parts of masses $m$ and $2m$. Mass $m$ moves north with a velocity of $2v$ and mass $2m$ moves south with a velocity of $v$. Calculate the total change in linear momentum of the system as a result of the explosion.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff2acbba-2403-4a67-b180-9dbd6ab500fe/images/84602be2-5f8f-4366-be5d-8b3dd6c7f170/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.56.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Zero
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $1.5mv$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $4mv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $6mv$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in the momentum of the system in the explosion is zero, as the system is isolated and therefore momentum is conserved.

list.title: Question 77
list.content:
An object is initially moving in the horizontal direction with momentum $p_0$. A constant vertical force $F$ is applied to the object.
Which of the following graphs shows how the magnitude of the total momentum of the object $p$ varies with time $t$?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/44c325c8-ef7f-4e51-993f-f7e7d714c26a/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.16.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/2c6a0ef1-0a2a-4b09-b076-874be65c06c7/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.17.23%E2%80%AFPM.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/b1c509bd-5de0-4123-8c03-e34e1ab2d617/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.17.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/e8ba70a7-1b38-4d5b-9236-c368ea47a2d8/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.17.36%E2%80%AFPM.png)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$F\Delta t=\Delta p$ so the amount of momentum added increases linearly with time.
However the total momentum is the vector sum (not the algebraic sum) of the momenta. Initial momentum $p_0$ and added momentum $Ft$ are perpendicular.
Refer to the diagram below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/975a1976-eca9-4d1d-8c22-3678a3326559/images/2c1efa10-931e-4f50-8b4a-3599850a1dd4/image.png)


When $Ft$ is much smaller than $p_0$:  $p\approx p_0$ - graph will be flat close to $t=0$.
When $Ft$ is much larger than $p_0$, the effect of $p_0$ on the total momentum will become insignificant: $p\approx Ft$ - the shape of graph will tend towards a straight line with gradient of $F$.
Answer is B.
A is incorrect - This graph tends towards a constant value, but momentum will continue to increase.
C is incorrect - momentum will not increase linearly. $p^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2$
D is incorrect - There is no reason to think momentum will increase, plateau and then increase again.
$\underline{\text{Alternative solution}}$
using Pythagoras, we can see that


- $p^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2$

When $t=0$: $p=p_0$
Let us find $t$ such that $p=2p_0$ (the time at which momentum has doubled).


- $(2p_0 )^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2$
- $4p_0^2=p_0^2+(Ft)^2$
- $3p_0^2=(Ft)^2$
- $\sqrt{3p_0}=Ft$
- $t=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{F}$

Now if we consider the momentum at half this time $t=\dfrac{\sqrt{3p_0}}{2F}$


- $p^2=p_0^2+\Bigl(F \dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2F}\Bigr)^2 $
- $p^2=p_0^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2}\Bigr)^2 $
- $p^2=p_0^2+\dfrac{3}{4} p_0^2$
- $p^2=1.75p_0^2$
- $p=\sqrt{1.75}p_0 < 1.5p_0$

When $t=0$: $p=p_0$
When $t=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{2F}$: $p<1.5p_0$
When $t=\dfrac{\sqrt{3 p_0}}{F}$: $p<2p_0$
So curve must be B.

list.title: Question 78
list.content:
A firecracker is at rest just before exploding. Upon exploding, the firecracker splits into two unequal parts which are projected in exactly opposite directions. Which of the following must be true?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The total kinetic energy of the firecracker remains unchanged before and after the explosion.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The kinetic energy of the two parts after the explosion is identical.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The total momentum of the firecracker is unchanged after the explosion.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The velocities of the two parts are exactly equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
A. Incorrect. Because $E_k$ changed from zero to non-zero because the chemical potential energy in the firecracker is converted into kinetic energy which is divided between the two parts after the explosion.
B. Incorrect. Because $E_k=\left(\dfrac{p^2}{2m}\right)$ and the momenta must be equal, the kinetic energies must be unequal as the masses are not equal.
C. Correct. Momentum is always conserved in any process for an isolated system.
D. Incorrect. Because since momentum is conserved, unequal parts must have unequal velocities.

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
An object of mass $m$ rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass $M$ is connected to it via a frictionless pulley. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the surface and the object of mass $m$ is $\mu$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05d91a08-8de6-402e-8cdc-523e298b8e9e/images/3cc24a0e-924d-46a5-9506-bc8a67c37f66/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%201.47.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


When the object of mass $M$ is released, the objects accelerate. What is the acceleration of the system?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{gM}{M+m}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{gm}{M+m}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{g(\mu m-M)}{M+m}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The resultant force is the difference between the weight of the object of mass $M$ and the force of friction between the object of mass $m$ and the rough surface.


- $F_{net} = F_g - F_f =m_{total}a$

Weight of the object


- $F_g= Mg$

Friction on mass $m$


- $F_f= \mu mg$



- $M_{total}=M+m$

Substituting into the first equation,


- $Mg - \mu mg = (M+m)a$

By rearranging;


- $a = \dfrac{g(M-\mu m)}{M+m}$

Therefore, The answer is C.

list.title: Question 80
list.content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energy $E_p$ when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
In terms of $E_p$, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$E_p$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $E_p$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$E_p$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.25$E_p$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using Hooke's law,


- $F=k\Delta x$

the elastic potential energy is


- $E_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta x$.

In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equation


- $F=k\Delta x$.

When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

list.title: Question 81
list.content: Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png) - State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction [2] - Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface. [3] - The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s$^{-2}$. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40. [2] - Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface $\checkmark$
  The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forces OR static friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value  $\checkmark$



- Component of weight parallel to the incline = $\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ and tension in thread $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N $\checkmark$
  Static friction = $\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  coefficient of static friction = $\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg$ 0.96 $\checkmark$ (0.94 to 0.96 accepted)
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weight $W$, tension $T$ static friction $F_f$ and normal force $N$;
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)


  Weight has two components parallel to the incline $W_h$ and perpendicular to the incline $W_v$;
  
  
  - $W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15$ N down to the slope

  The tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;
  
  
  - $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N

  The forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;
  
  
  - $\begin{aligned}
     W_h+F_f&=T\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     15+F_f&=39\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
     \end{aligned}$

  By using the equation of static friction;
  $\begin{aligned}
   F_f&=\mu R\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu&=0.96\\
   \end{aligned}$
  
- The dynamic friction = $\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $a$ = $\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg $     1.5 m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weight $W_h$ down to the slope and dynamic friction $F_f$ up the slope. The dynamic friction;
  
  
  - $F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10$ N
  - $F_{net}=ma$
  - $14.7-10.2=3.0a$
  - $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$

  
- displacement of the mass = $\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

  OR
  Heat lost due to friction = $\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v$ = $\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg$     2.4 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;
  
  
  - $s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0$ m

  By using a suvat equation;
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$ while $u=0$, $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$, and $s=2.0$ m
  - $v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0$
  - $v=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

  This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;
  The energy dissipated due to friction is
  
  
  - $Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20$ J

  and the change in gravitational potential energy can be found by
  
  
  - $\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29$ J

  The gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore
  
  
  - $29=\Delta E_k+20$
  - $\Delta E_k=9.0$ J

  Solving for speed gives
  
  
  - $\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 82
list.content:
A CD stores data on its surface on a number of concentric circular tracks of different radii. The radius of the first track is 25 mm and that of the last track is 60 mm as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5876f1f4-bbfd-49ce-9d68-a65199d28398/images/0607fc72-de98-4cca-bec1-2a0da763a526/PH0633.png)



The data from the CD is read by rotating the disk under a laser system  where the tangential speed is always 1.5 m s$^{-1}$ for the track being read.
Which of the following is correct about the angular speed of the first track $\omega_1$ and the angular speed of the last track $\omega_2$?

$\omega_1$ $\omega_2$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $60$ rad s$^{-1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$Same as $\omega_1$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $60$ rad s$^{-1}$Less than $\omega_1$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $25$ rad s$^{-1}$Same as $\omega_1$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $25$ rad s$^{-1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ Greater than $\omega_1$ $\hspace{1.5em}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since the tangential speed is constant for all tracks, then the angular speed is different for each track.
The angular speed of the first track:


- $\omega_1=\dfrac{v}{r_1}$
- $\omega_1=\dfrac{1.5}{25\times{10}^{-3}}$

$\hspace{2.9em}$ $=60$ rad s$^{-1}$
The angular speed of the last track will be less than that of the first track since the angular speed is inversely proportional to the radius of rotation.

list.title: Question 83
list.content: The rotor ride in the amusement park consists of a vertical cylinder that rotates around its axis. Its floor drops down when it rotates fast enough, so that a person inside it is held against its walls. The walls are made of rubberized material such that the coefficient of static friction $\mu <1$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/281ae2f3-a2fa-4ee9-a300-6c714b1e0255/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.40.27%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by Clker-Free-Vector-Images from Pixabay - https://pixabay.com/]}}$ - Explain in terms of forces how a person can remain suspended against the wall without falling when the floor is dropped. [3] - - Show that the maximum period of rotation for the person to remain at rest relative to the wall is given by $\hspace{1em}$ $T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}$ Where $r$ = radius of the cylinder $\mu$ = coefficient of static friction between the wall and the person [3] - The radius of the rotor is 4.5 m and the coefficient of static friction of the walls is 0.40. Calculate the angular speed of the cylinder necessary for this situation. [3] - - To make the ride more exciting, an idea of tilting the axis of the rotor by an angle $\theta$ is discussed. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/a0617516-bba2-4b35-88e7-31ebb403eb3d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) Draw and label the free body diagram of a person at point A when the ride is in operation. [1] - The cylinder is tilted a full 90$\degree$ so that its axis of rotation is now horizontal. Deduce whether the minimum speed of rotation for this orientation is greater than or less than the minimum speed for the original situation with a vertical axis of rotation. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The normal force provides the centripetal force, $\checkmark$
  Minimum speed is required / relation between normal force and linear speed. $\checkmark$
  Friction balances the weight. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The friction force of the wall on the person is affected by the normal force
  
  
  - $\hspace{1em}$ $F_f=\mu\ F_N$

  The normal force of the walls in this situation is the centripetal force, which means it is affected by the linear velocity
  
  
  - $\hspace{1em}$ $F_N=F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$

  This means that, there's a minimum speed at which the magnitude of the normal force will be enough so that the friction force of the walls will balance the weight of the person and keep it at rest without falling.
  The person's weight is in equilibrium with the friction force of the wall.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/e2ca7f98-5e73-47f7-bb08-885c0300b78c/PH0651aaaa.png)


  
- 
  - $\hspace{1.5em}$ $F_f=\mu\ F_N=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $F_f\ = mg$ therefore $v^2=\dfrac{rg}{\mu}$ $\checkmark$
    - $T=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v} \dfrac{v^2}{r} = \dfrac{4 \pi^{2r}}{T^2}$ $\checkmark$

    substitute and solve to get answer
    
    
    - $\ll\ T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}\gg $

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The normal force is the centripetal force
    
    
    - $F_N=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$

    And the friction force is given by
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu\ F_N$

    Then
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$

    Since the friction force is in equilibrium with the weight
    
    
    - $F_f=mg$

    Then
    $\hspace{1em}$ $\begin{aligned}
    \mu\frac{mv^2}{r}\ &=mg\\
    \mu\frac{v^2}{r}\ &=g\\
    v^2\ &=\frac{rg}{\mu}\\
    v\ &=\sqrt{\frac{rg}{\mu}}\\
    \end{aligned}$
    Since the linear speed is given by
    
    
    - $v=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}$

    Then
    
    
    - $T=\dfrac{2\pi r}{v}=2\pi\ r\sqrt{\dfrac{\mu}{rg}}$
    - $T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}$

    OR
    Since
    
    
    - $\dfrac{v^2}{r}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}$

    Then
    
    
    - $T^2=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2}{v^2}=\dfrac{4\pi^2r^2\mu}{rg}$
    - $T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}$

    
  - 
    
    - $T=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}\gg=2.69\ \ll\textrm{ s}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    - $\omega=\ll\dfrac{2\pi}{T}\gg$
    - $\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\omega=2.33\ \ll\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The angular speed is related to the linear speed by
    
    
    - $v=\omega\ r$

    And
    
    
    - $v=\dfrac{2\pi r}{T}$

    Then
    
    
    - $\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{T}$

    Since
    
    
    - $T=\sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi^2\mu r}{g}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(4{)(\pi}^2\right)\left(0.40\right)\left(4.5\right)}{\left(9.8\right)}}=2.69$ s

    Then
    
    
    - $\omega=\dfrac{2\pi}{2.69}=2.33$ rad s$^{-1}$

    

- 
  - Correct orientation AND labelling of vectors. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bc818c3-b41c-4cb7-a344-ddead3976ef0/images/d79f0d1d-d21c-4838-8097-f4b718e5ff44/PH0651c_MS.png)


    
  - Horizontal axis of rotation: $v^2  = rg$ $\checkmark$
    Vertical axis of rotation: $v^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}$  $\checkmark$
    $\mu < 1$,
therefore vertical minimum speed is greater than the horizontal minimum speed of rotation. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
For the horizontal axis of rotation, the minimum speed occurs when the centripetal acceleration at the top of the motion is equal to the acceleration due to gravity, resulting in a normal force of zero.
    
    
    - $\dfrac{v^2}{r} = g$
    - $v^2  = rg$

    For the vertical axis,
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = F_N$
    - $F_F = \mu F_N = mg$ therefore $F_N= \dfrac{mg}{\mu}$

    Which gives
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r} = \dfrac{mg}{\mu}$
    - $v^2  = \dfrac{(rg)}{\mu}$

    Because the question states that $\mu < 1$
    The minimum speed for the vertical rotational axis is greater than the minimum speed for the horizontal axis of rotation.

list.title: Question 84
list.content:
The diagram shows the forces acting on a block as it slides down an inclined plane with constant acceleration. $W$ is the weight of the block, $F$ is the friction force, $\mu_d$ is the coefficient of dynamic friction and $g$ is the gravitational field strength. The plane is inclined at an angle $\theta$ to the horizontal.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6dd9f02b-50c5-4738-bb6a-b711f780ca5f/images/0f6c937d-dd84-46b7-894a-f968f5aed254/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.55.44%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which expression gives the acceleration of the block?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $g\sin\theta - g\mu_d\cos\theta$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $g\cos\theta - g\mu_d\sin\theta$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $W\sin\theta - W\mu_d\cos\theta$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $W\cos\theta - W\mu_d\sin\theta$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To solve this, we should resolve the weight into components along the slope
Component of weight along the slope = $mg\sin \theta$
Normal reaction force ($F_N$) is given by $mg\cos\theta$
Dynamic friction = $\mu_dF_N = \mu_d\,mg\cos \theta$
Apply Newton's second law: $F_{net}=mg\sin\theta - \mu_d\,mg\cos\theta =ma$
