Dividing both sides by mass gives
$a=g\sin\theta - \mu_d\,g\cos\theta $

list.title: Question 85
list.content: Three identical cylinders sit inside a cup. Their radius of each is 5 cm and their centres of mass are marked in the diagram. The lines connecting the centres of the masses pass through the contact points between the cylinders. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/28eb4292-7e34-4dd1-b84e-523fa72ba475/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.33.38%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - Draw and label the free-body diagram for the cylinder $M_3$ [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8ceca09c-66d6-413b-a0a3-dbab45457fbd/PH0560-A.png) - - For analysis purposes, the three cylinders can at times be considered as a single object consisting of the mass of the all cylinders. Explain why this simplification may be useful. [1] - The reaction force of the ground on $M_3$ is $30$ N. Show that the mass of each cylinder is around 1.0 kg. [2] - Determine the force that mass $M_3$ exerts on $M_1$ [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\hspace{1em}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/5079963b-144c-4400-ada3-9b1b31a00144/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


  Correct direction and labeling of the forces $\checkmark$
  The reaction force of the ground is greater than the other forces $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - Interactions  between the cylinders can be ignored/it allows only external forces to be analyzed  $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Every cylinder experiences forces due to their weights and forces from the other cylinders and the container walls. To decrease complexity in representing forces on the objects, the cylinders are simplified as combined to form one object so that forces between the cylinders can be ignored and only external forces can be considered.
    
  - Total weight of the cylinder = reaction of the ground on $M_3$
    Weight of each cylinder = $\dfrac{30}{3}=10\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $m=\ll\dfrac{10}{9.81}=\gg$       $1.02\ \ll\textrm{kg}\gg$ $\checkmark$

    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When the three cylinders are considered as a single mass, the forces between the cylinders can be ignored. The vertical forces acting on the combined  masses are the weight $W_t$ of all discs and the R reaction force of the ground on the $M_3$.
    
    
    - $W_t=R$
    - $W_t=30$ N

    Therefore, the weight of one disc $W$
    
    
    - $W=\dfrac{30}{3}=10$ N

    So, the mass $m$ of one disc
    
    
    - $m=\dfrac{10}{9.81}=1.02$ kg

    

- The weight of the $M_1$ is balanced by the vertical component of the force from $M_3$ on $M_1$ $\checkmark$
  The reaction of $M_3$ on $M_1=\ll\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=\gg$ 11.5 N $\checkmark$
  OR
  Reaction of the $M_3$ on the $M_1$ = Reaction of the $M_1$ on the $M_3$
  AND
  Reaction of the $M_2$ on the $M_3$ = Reaction of the $M_1$ on the $M_3$
  Reaction=$\ll\dfrac{N-W}{2(\cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{\left(2\right)\left(0.87\right)}=\gg11.5\ \ll\textrm{N}\gg$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The weight of $M_1$ is supported by the force of reaction $R_{31}$ of the $M_3$ on $M_1$. Therefore
  $W(\cos\theta)=R_{31}$  where $\theta$ is the angle shown on the diagram below.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/8759817a-d2cf-403b-9d88-6f93199347be/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


  The length L can be found with the Pythagoras theorem
  
  
  - $L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7$ cm

  Finding $\cos\theta$
  
  
  - $\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87$
  - $R_{31}=\dfrac{W}{\cos\theta}$
  - $R_{31}=\dfrac{10}{0.87}=11.5$ N

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}$: 
According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reaction $R_{31}$ of the $M_3$ on $M_1$ equals the force of the reaction  $R_{13}$ of the $M_1$ on $M_3$. The vertical component of the $R_{13}$ can be found with the help of geometry
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/9338dc86-1aa1-47bc-9412-01f90ad79a7c/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.48.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


  The length L can be found with the Pythagorean theorem
  
  
  - $L=\sqrt{{10}^2-5^2}=8.7$ cm

  Finding $\cos\theta$
  
  
  - $\cos\theta=\dfrac{8.67}{10}=0.87$

  According to Newton's Third Law, the force of reaction $R_{31}$ of the $M_3$ on $M_1$ equals the force of the reaction  $R_{13}$ of the $M_1$ on $M_3$. The vertical component of the $R_{13}$ can be found with the help of geometry
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c1073f-1058-406c-9d31-7ea31814fde3/images/fd3e2f7a-53c9-48d7-a7ce-91d39a71b611/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%209.34.36%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)


  The reaction of $M_2$ on the $M_3$ and the reaction of $M_1$ on the $M_3$ must be equal to each other to cancel each other's horizontal components. $M_3$ is in equilibrium and vertical forces acting on cancel each other
  
  
  - $2(R_{13})(cos\theta)+W=N$
  - $R_{13}=\dfrac{N-W}{2(cos\theta)}=\dfrac{30-10\ }{(2)(0.87)}=11.5\ N$

list.title: Question 86
list.content:
Block $A$ of mass $m_A=3.0$ kg rests above the flat horizontal surface of block $B$ of mass $m_B=6.0$ kg, which in turn rests on a smooth horizontal surface as shown.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/916d5984-df39-4104-8ae4-f0b1bc8e95d8/images/95a83caf-67bf-4f98-b1f3-d2746f45ddb2/Screensh0ot%202025-05-27%20at%201.33.09%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between $A$ and $B$ are $\mu_s=0.2$ and $\mu_k=0.1$ respectively. A horizontal force of $F=7.0$ N is applied towards the right on block $A$. Assuming acceleration due to gravity $g \approx 10$ m s$^{-2}$, the direction and magnitude of acceleration $a_B$ of block $B$ are:

$\hspace{1em}$ Direction of $\bf{a_B}$ $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$ Magnitude of $\bf{a_B}$ $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$To the left$1.0$ m s$^{-2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$To the left$0.5$ m s$^{-2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$To the right$1.0$ m s$^{-2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$To the right$0.5$ m s$^{-2}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The normal contact force on $A$, $R_A=m_A g=(3.0$ kg) (10 m s$^{-2})=30$ N
(Contact force from $B$ supports the weight of $A$).
The maximum friction on between $A$ and $B$ is $F_{s}=\mu_s R_A=(0.2)(30$ N) = 6.0 N.
The applied force $F = 7.0\,N > f_{s,max}=6.0$ N.
Therefore, block $A$ slides on block $B$, reducing the final frictional force between the blocks to kinetic friction, $F_k=\mu_k R_A=0.1 \times 30$ N=3.0 N.
On $A$, this friction will be to the left (as it is being pulled to the right).
Since friction on $B$ is a reaction to friction on $A$, it will be to the right, and equal to $3.0$ N. (Newton's third law).
Using Newton's second law, the acceleration of $B$, $a_B=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m_B} = \dfrac{f_k}{m_B} = \dfrac{3.0\textrm{ N}}{6.0\textrm{ kg}}=0.5$ m s$^{-2}$.
Note:

- Friction is to the left on A. On B it is to the right.
- Acceleration will be 1.0 m s$^{-2}$ if you use maximum static friction. Kinetic friction kicks in, since $F(=7.0\textrm{ N}) > F_{s,max}=\mu_s m_A g=6.0$ N.

list.title: Question 87
list.content:
A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?

$\hspace{1.5em}$The motion of the ball$\hspace{1.5em}$Acceleration$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing downUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upDownwards$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing down$\hspace{1.5em}$ Downwards $\hspace{1.5em}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.
The buoyancy :


- $F_B = {\rho}_{liquid}Vg$

Weight:


- $W=mg={\rho}_{ball}Vg$

Since the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.

list.title: Question 88
list.content: A conical pendulum consists of a mass $m$ tied to a $22$ cm string that makes an angle $\theta$ with the vertical as shown in the diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d5e3e99-f522-48a4-b057-82be86227576/images/8c9185d6-2ea7-4847-9716-c70ba2b3ba78/PH06421a.png) - Mass of the bob = $8.0$ g - Angle with the vertical $\theta = 20\degree$ - Draw the free body diagram of the bob in the given position. [2] - - Show that angular velocity $\omega$ is given by $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{g\tan\theta\ }{r}}$ [2] - Calculate the linear velocity of the bob. [2] - Determine the tension in the string. [2] - - Explain the effect of increasing the angular speed ω on the angle θ. [3] - The maximum tension the string can provide is $1.5$ N. Determine the maximum angular speed. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\hspace{2.3cm}\\$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d5e3e99-f522-48a4-b057-82be86227576/images/1fddbe16-b62d-4155-875e-84c9507e013b/PH0642-2a.png)


  Gravitational force vertically downwards. $\checkmark$
  Tension force in the direction of the string $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 1}}$
    
    
    - $m\omega^2r=T\sin\theta$  $\checkmark$
    - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta\ }$ $\checkmark$

    Substitution of second equation into first shown to obtain the correct expression $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 2}}$
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=T\sin\theta$  $\checkmark$
    - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta }$ $\checkmark$

    Substitution of second equation into first shown to obtain the correct expression $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\omega=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{g\tan\theta\ }{r}}\gg$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The centripetal force is the horizontal component of the tension.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d5e3e99-f522-48a4-b057-82be86227576/images/46f76483-f229-438d-a0b1-01c307410ada/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.23.37%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


    $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 1}}$
    
    
    - $F_c=m\omega^2r=T\sin\theta\ $

    and
    
    
    - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta\ }$

    Then
    
    
    - $m\omega^2r=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta\ } {\sin}\theta\ $
    - $\omega^2=\dfrac{g\,{\tan}\ \theta\ }{r}$
    - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{g\,{\tan}\ \theta\ }{r}}$

    $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 2}}$
    
    
    - $F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=T\sin\theta$

    and
    
    
    - $T\cos\theta\ =mg$
    - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta}$

    Then
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\dfrac{mg}{{\cos} \,\theta}\sin\theta\ $
    - $v^2=rg\tan\theta\ $
    - $v=\sqrt{rg\tan\theta\ }$

    The angular speed is given by
    
    
    - $\omega=\dfrac{v}{r}$

    Then
    
    
    - $\omega=\dfrac{\sqrt{rg\tan\theta }}{r}$
    - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{g\tan\theta }{r}}$

    
    - $r = 22 \,sin (20\degree)=7.5$ cm $\checkmark$
      $v=\ll\sqrt{rg\tan\theta\ }\gg$
      $=\sqrt{(7.5\times{10}^{-2})(9.81)(\tan20 })  $
      or
      $\omega=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{g\tan\theta}{r}}\gg$
      $=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(9.81\right)\left(\tan20 \right)}{\left(7.5\times{10}^{-2}\right)}}\gg$
      $=\ll6.9\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$
      $v=\ll\omega r\gg=(6.9\ )(7.5\times{10}^{-2})$
      $v=$ 0.52 $ \ll$ m s$^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$
      $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
      
      
      - $r = 22 \sin (20\degree)=7.5$ cm
      - $F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=T\sin\theta$

      and
      
      
      - $T\cos\theta=mg$
      - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta}$

      Then
      
      
      - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta}\sin\theta$
      - $v^2=rg\tan\theta$
      - $v=\sqrt{rg\tan\theta}$
      - $=\sqrt{(7.5\times{10}^{-2})(9.81)(\tan20 })  $
      - $=0.52$ m s$^{-1}$

      or
      
      
      - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{g\tan\theta}{r}}$
      - $=\sqrt{\dfrac{\left(9.81\right)\left(\tan20 \right)}{\left(7.5\times{10}^{-2}\right)}}$
      - $=6.9$ rad s$^{-1}$
      - $v=\omega r=(6.9\ )(7.5\times{10}^{-2})$
      - $v= 0.52$ m s$^{-1}$

      
    - $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 1}}$
      
      
      - $T=\ll\dfrac{mv^2}{r\sin\theta}\gg=\dfrac{(8.0\times{10}^{-3}){(0.52)}^2}{(7.5\times{10}^{-2})(\sin20)\ }$ $\checkmark$
      - $T=$ 0.08 $\ll$ N $\gg $ $\checkmark$

      $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 2}}$
      
      
      - $T=\ \ll\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta}\gg$
$=\dfrac{(8.0\times{10}^{-3})(9.81)}{\cos20}$ $\checkmark$
      - $T=$ 0.08 $\ll$ N $\gg$ $\checkmark$

      $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
$\underline{\textrm{Alternative 1}}$
      Since
      
      
      - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=T\sin\theta$

      Then
      
      
      - $T=\dfrac{mv^2}{r\sin\theta}$
      - $T=\dfrac{(8\times{10}^{-3}){(0.52)}^2}{(10\times{10}^{-2})(\sin20)}=0.08$ N

      $\underline{\textrm{Alternative 2}}$
      
      
      - $T\cos\theta=mg$
      - $T=\dfrac{mg}{\cos\theta}$
      - $T=\dfrac{(8\times{10}^{-3})(9.81)}{\cos20}=0.08$ N

      


- 
  - The vertical component of the tension force remains constant, as it is equal to the weight of the bob. $\checkmark$
    The horizontal component of the tension provides the centripetal force, which increases as $\omega$ increases. $\checkmark$
    Because the horizontal component increases while the vertical component stays constant, the angle $\theta$ will increase with $\omega$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d5e3e99-f522-48a4-b057-82be86227576/images/574b3e88-8d74-4a9f-a012-a3a76bfbb281/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.21.52%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    
    - $T\cos\theta=mg$

    and
    
    
    - $T\sin\theta=F_c$

    Therefore,
    
    
    - $tan\theta=\dfrac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}=\dfrac{F_c}{mg}$

    Because $mg$ is constant and $F_c$ is increasing as ω increases,
    $\tan\theta$ and therefore $\theta$ increase as $\omega$ increases.
    
  - $mg = (0.008)(9.8) = 0.08$ N
    0.08 N $\ll$ 1.5 N
    Therefore centripetal force is equal to the tension force/rope is almost horizontal/θ very close to $90\degree$. $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\omega=\ll\sqrt{\dfrac{T}{mr}}\gg$
    - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.5}{\left(8\times{10}^{-3}\right)\left(22\times{10}^{-2}\right)}}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\omega=$ 29.2 $\ll\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Gravitational force is
    
    
    - $mg = (0.008)(9.8) = 0.08$ N

    The maximum tension is 1.5 N, which is the resultant of the vertical component of tension (mg) and the horizontal component of the tension, $F_c$.
    Therefore,
    
    
    - ${1.5}^2={0.08}^2+\ {F_c}^2$

    Solving gives
    
    
    - $F_c=\ 1.49787\ =\ 1.5$ N

    This shows that the centripetal force is effectively equal to the tension force and the string very close to horizontal.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d5e3e99-f522-48a4-b057-82be86227576/images/38a28a4c-75ef-4bab-a13d-d3f6399c84a9/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%203.58.49%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    
    
    - $m\omega^2r=T$

    
    
    - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{T}{mr}}$
    - $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.5}{(8\times{10}^{-3})(22\times{10}^{-2})}}=29.2$ rad s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 89
list.content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)


A cart of mass $m$ enters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radius $R$ with a horizontal speed $u$ at the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.
Its speed at the bottom of the loop $u$, is given by:



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{5gR}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{4gR}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{gR}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{2gR}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Conservation of energy:
$E_k + E_p$ at the bottom of the circle = $E_k + E_p$ at the top of the circle.


- (I)$\hspace{0.8em}$ $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)$
- $\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gR$

Centripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.
Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}$
Substituting this result into (I) gives


- $u^2=gR+4gR$
- $u=\sqrt{5gR}$

list.title: Question 90
list.content:
A ball of mass $m$ strikes a vertical wall with a speed of $v$. It bounces back with the same speed. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the incoming ball is $\theta_1$. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the ball after the bounce is  $\theta_2$. During the collision, the only force that acts on the ball is normal to the wall.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ad019d36-8753-4d72-a8aa-514000db4270/images/15fb46e9-c502-4194-ac44-81c73f291932/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.42.17%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


What is the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos\,\theta_1)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin\,\theta_1)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin(\theta_1+\theta_2))$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos(\theta_1+\theta_2))$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The question states that the only force from the wall on the ball during the collision is perpendicular to the surface. Due to the absence of a vertical force, there will be no change in the vertical component of the momentum of the ball, and all of the momentum change is in the horizontal direction.
Because the collision is elastic, the speed of the ball is unchanged in the collision. As the vertical component of the velocity is unchanged, it follows that the magnitude of the horizontal component of the velocity is also unchanged.
Given that the magnitudes of the components are both unchanged, the angles $\theta_1\ $and $\theta_2$ must be equal.
It has been determined that the only change in momentum is in the horizontal direction.
Therefore,


- $∆p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}$
- $p_{ih}=mv\,(\sin\,\theta_1)$

and


- $p_{fh}=-mv(\sin\,\theta_2)$
- $\Delta p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}=-mv\sin\,θ_2-mv\sin\,θ_1$

But


- $\theta_1=\theta_2$

Therefore


- $\Delta p_h=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)$

Thus


- $\Delta p=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)$

list.title: Question 91
list.content: A ball of mass $1.6$ kg is dropped from a very high building. The only forces acting on the ball are the force of gravity and air resistance. The graph shows the variation of the vertical velocity $v$ of the ball with time $t$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db291db8-8a1d-4c99-bd14-40785346db3c/images/f8d68b0f-5361-4c95-a869-cad21dc827fe/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%201.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png) - - Define terminal speed. [1] - State the terminal speed of the ball. [1] - Estimate the vertical displacement of the ball during the $10.0$ s of motion. [2] - - Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the ball at $t=2.0$ s. [2] - Determine the magnitude of the vertical component of the force of air resistance at $t=2.0$ s [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The maximum speed/velocity  obtained by an object during  motion in a fluid/gas/air/liquid $\checkmark$
  - 18 $\ll\textrm{ m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the graph, the velocity of the ball increases and then stays constant at 18 m s$^{-1}$.
    

- Any reference to the area under the graph being equal to the displacement. $\checkmark$
  $125\pm10$ $\ll\textrm{m, downwards}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the velocity-time graph is equal to the ball's displacement. The area can be calculated by using the small square approximation. The area $A_s$ of each small square:
  
  
  - $A_s=(0.2)(1)=0.2$ m

  There are approximately 625 small   squares. Therefore, the total area A or displacement:
  
  
  - $A=(625)(0.2)=125$ m

  Note that displacement is a vector quantity and so a direction should be stated. In this case, the ball is falling so the direction of the displacement is downwards.
  
- 
  - Reference to use of the gradient of the graph to find instantaneous acceleration. $\checkmark$
    $2.8\ \pm\ 0.5$ $\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg $ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at a given time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/db291db8-8a1d-4c99-bd14-40785346db3c/images/63f6af18-586a-453f-95d2-612df55c9d96/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%201.42.12%E2%80%AFPM.png)


  - $mg-ma=$ air resistance $\checkmark$
    $(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)=$ air  resistance $\checkmark$
    11 $\ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
    ECF for the use of the answer of (c) (i) to determine the acceleration
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The vertical resultant force $F_{net}$ acting on the mass:
    
    
    - $F_{net}$ = Weight - Air Resistance

    or
    
    
    - $F_{net} = F_g - F_d$

    and
    
    
    - $F_{net}$ = $ma$

    Therefore
    
    
    - $ma = F_g - F_d$
    - $F_d = mg - ma$
    - $F_d=(1.6)(9.81)-(1.6)(2.8)$
    - $F_d = 11.3$ N

list.title: Question 92
list.content:
A mass $m$ attached to a string is moving in a horizontal circular motion as shown. The tension on the string is $T$, and the angle with the vertical is $\theta$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f897e16-36d2-4eba-9082-d03dcb67e4bf/images/a13df1c4-6075-41b6-b663-837340c74c7f/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.29.13%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Below are three statements about this motion:


- I. $\hspace{1em}$ Centripetal force = $mg$ $\tan(\theta)$.
- II.$\hspace{0.8em}$ Total gravitational and kinetic energy of the mass is constant.
- III. $\hspace{0.4em}$ If the rope is cut, the mass will fall downwards with a straight line trajectory.

Which of the statements are correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Only I
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Statement I is correct: 
$\hspace{3em}$ $T$ $\cos(\theta)$ = $mg$,  which gives $T = \dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}$
$\hspace{3em}$ centripetal force ($F_c$) = $T$ $\sin(\theta)$
Substituting $\dfrac{mg}{\cos(\theta)}$ for $T$ in the second equation:
$\hspace{3em}$ $F_c=mg$ $\dfrac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}$ = $mg$ $\tan(\theta)$.
Statement II is correct: 
The path is a horizontal plane, therefore gravitational potential energy is constant. No work is done, therefore kinetic energy is constant. Total mechanical energy is constant.
Statement III is false: 
The mass has a horizontal velocity during this motion. When the rope is cut, the only force will be the weight, therefore it will move in a projectile motion starting with a horizontal velocity, following a vertical parabolic path (not fall directly downwards).

list.title: Question 93
list.content:
A mass $Y$ attached to a rope is moving in uniform circular motion on a frictionless table as shown on the diagram. The circular path of constant radius $r$ is shown with the dotted line. The mass $X$ is hanging from the lower end of the rope.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a40671b-b837-40f6-a740-2d3097378023/images/b246b165-344f-45e4-b1c6-9c5afe234227/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.44.48%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The masses of $X$ and $Y$ can be adjusted. What independent adjustments to either mass $X$ or mass $Y$ could produce uniform circular motion at a lower speed $v$, but with the same radius $r$?

$\hspace{2em}$ Mass $Y$ $\hspace{2em}$ $\hspace{2em}$ Mass $X$ $\hspace{2em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$increaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$increasedecrease$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreasedecrease
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Centripetal force is provided by the weight of the hanging mass $X$. We can substitute $X$ in to the equation $F_g= mg$ and $Y$ into the centripetal force equation:


- $mg = \dfrac{mv^2}{r}$
- $Xg=\dfrac{Yv^2}{r}$

To maintain the same radius with a decrease in $v$, this equation should hold.
When the linear speed decreases, therefore to keep the equation balanced, the mass $Y$ should increase, or $X$ should decrease.

list.title: Question 94
list.content: Tennis ball $A$ travels along a flat, frictionless surface at a speed of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$ and collides with an identical tennis ball $B$ that is initially stationary. After the collision, ball $A$ moves off at a speed of 1.8 m s$^{-1}$, at an angle of $27\degree$ from its original direction of motion as shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7d760ea6-21c8-472e-a179-872ea8743c87/images/247c3ad5-0534-43f7-a718-2b7dc091ebf0/Screenshot%202025-09-24%20at%209.56.52%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Show that the speed of ball $B$ after the collision is around 1.6 m s$^{-1}$. [3] - Deduce whether the collision is elastic. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\hspace{1.8em}$ $m(3)=m(1.8\cos27\degree)+m(v_{B\parallel})$
  AND
  
  
  - $0=(1.8\sin27\degree)+m(v_{B\perp})$

  OR
  
  
  - $\ll v_{B\parallel}=\gg1.4$ m s$^{-1}$ seen

  OR
  
  
  - $\ll v_{B\perp}=-\gg0.82$ m s$^{-1}$ seen $\checkmark$
  - $\ll v_{B\parallel}=\gg1.4$ m s$^{-1}$

  AND
  
  
  - $\ll v_{B\perp}=-\gg0.82$ m s$^{-1}$ seen $\checkmark$
  - speed = $\sqrt{1.4^2+0.82^2}= \answer{1.6\ \ce{m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
This is a 2D collision where ball $A$ is deflected at an angle, and ball $B$ starts at rest. Since there are no external forces, we apply conservation of momentum directions parallel and perpendicular to the initial motion of the ball.
  Resolving the velocities after into parallel and perpendicular components (note that the angle $\theta$ is unknown)
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7d760ea6-21c8-472e-a179-872ea8743c87/images/e203463c-506d-4625-83c0-37cb917df155/Screenshot%202025-09-24%20at%209.58.07%E2%80%AFAM.png)


  In the direction parallel to the initial motion, we have:
  
  
  - $p_\textrm{before}=p_\textrm{after}$
  - $(0.058)(3)=(0.058)(1.8\cos27\degree)+(0.058)(v_{B\parallel})$
  - $(3)=(1.8\cos27\degree)+(v_{B\parallel})$
  - $v_{B\parallel}=3-1.8\cos27\degree=1.4$ m s$^{-1}$

  In the direction perpendicular to the initial motion, we have:
  
  
  - $p_\textrm{before}=p_\textrm{after}$
  - $(0.058)(0)=(0.058)(1.8\sin27\degree)+(0.058)(v_{B\perp})$
  - $(0)=(1.8\sin27\degree)+(v_{B\perp})$
  - $v_{B\perp}=-1.8\sin27\degree=-0.82$ m s$^{-1}$

  The speed of $B$ is the vector sum of the parallel and perpendicular components given by:
  
  
  - speed $=\sqrt{1.4^2+0.82^2}=1.6$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- KE before $=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(3^2)=0.26\ll\textrm{J}\gg$ (2sf)
  KE after $=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.6^2)+\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.8^2)=0.17\ll\textrm{J}\gg$ (2sf) $\checkmark$
  $0.26\ne0.17$ therefore the collision is not elastic $\checkmark$
  Allow $0.26\gt0.17$
  Allow any units or energy values in terms of $m$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
An elastic collision is one in which kinetic energy is conserved.
  The total kinetic energy before the collision is given by:
  
  
  - KE before $=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(3^2)+\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(0^2)=0.261$ J (3sf)

  The total kinetic energy after the collision is given by:
  
  
  - KE after $=\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.6^2)+\dfrac{1}{2}(0.058)(1.8^2)=0.170$ J (3sf)

  $0.26\ne0.16$ therefore, the collision is inelastic.
  Specifically, $0.26\gt0.17$ meaning that kinetic energy must have been lost in the collision (to heat or sound).

list.title: Question 95
list.content:
A mass moving with a constant speed $u$ encounters a rough surface and comes to a stop. The mass takes a time $t$ to stop after encountering the rough surface.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b39534bd-d7cb-4a8d-b23e-28aa458816db/images/37cb5cf0-1f11-43ce-af51-ed8a25184738/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.43.46%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The coefficient of dynamic friction between the rough surface and the mass is 0.40. Which of the following expressions gives the initial speed $u$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	0.2gt$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	0.4gt$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	gt$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	2.5gt$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When the mass is moving on the rough surface, the only horizontal force acting on it is dynamic friction. Due to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:


- $F_f = ma$

using $F_f=\mu_dF_N$ and $a=\dfrac{v-u}{t}$;


- $
  \mu_dF_N=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}$

$F_N=mg$,  therefore


- $\mu_dmg=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}$
- $\mu_dg=\dfrac{v-u}{t}$
- $\mu_dgt=v-u$
- $u=v-\mu_dgt$

By substituting the given values


- $u=0-0.4gt$
- $u=-0.4gt$

Because we are asked for the speed, we can remove the negative sign to get


- $u=0.4gt$

list.title: Question 96
list.content:
Three identical masses are connected as shown with a string that passes over an ideal pulley. The tension in the string connecting $m_1$ and $m_2$ is $T_1$. The tension of the string attached to $m_3$ is $T_2$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d40768-7d77-4ea9-8484-933e7732fbe0/images/a0a1b313-a16d-4619-920a-428e20554518/PH0546.png)


Which of the following is correct for $T_2$ and the acceleration of  $m_1$?

$\hspace{1.5em} \bf{T_2} \hspace{1.5em}$Acceleration of $\bf{m_1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2T_1$ $\dfrac{g}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2T_1$ $\dfrac{g}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3T_1}{2}$ $\dfrac{g}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3T_1}{2}$ $\dfrac{g}{2}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Let all masses be equal to $m$.
For the acceleration, we can assume all masses to be one system. There is a force of gravity of $2mg$ pulling the system one direction, and a force of gravity of $mg$ pulling the other direction.


- $F_{net}=2mg-mg=mg$

The total mass of the system is $3m$.
Therefore the acceleration of the system is the total mass of the system divided by the net force.


- $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{mg}{3m}=\dfrac{g}{3}$

When Newton's second law is applied to $m_1$;
$\begin{aligned}
ma&=F_{net}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
m \left( \dfrac{g}{3} \right) &=mg-T_1\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_1&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}$
When Newton's second law is applied to $m_3$
$\begin{aligned}
T_2-mg&=m\left(\frac{g}{3}\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_2&=\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}$
Therefore
$\hspace{2cm} T_2=2T_1$

list.title: Question 97
list.content:
A 200 g ball is moving in a horizontal circle shown with the dotted path in the diagram. The diameter of the bowl is 40 cm and the angular speed is $4\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a344575-2f87-453a-9f77-83741c73fc95/images/606c350c-ec49-41a6-a2c6-1c0319094817/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%209.56.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


What is the magnitude of the ball's centripetal acceleration?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $0.64\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	$3.2\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	$6.4\pi$ rad s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Cannot be determined with the given information.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The equation for the centripetal acceleration is $a_c=\omega^2r$.
Although $\omega$ is given in the question, the radius of the circular path is smaller than the radius of the bowl and no information is given to calculate it, therefore answer is D.

list.title: Question 98
list.content:
An object starts to move in a straight line under the effect of two opposite forces of $12$ N and $16$ N.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a815778-979e-489e-a9c5-299ceadae515/images/7eb3ac5e-250f-4986-a252-cdd3b70d9724/PH0548.png)


After $5$ s, the displacement of the object is $25$ m. What is the mass of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  1$ kg
- B. $\hspace{1em}  2$ kg
- C. $\hspace{1em}  3$ kg
- D. $\hspace{1em}  4$ kg
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From the equations of motion, the following expression can be written:


- $s=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2$

The object starts to move from rest, therefore u=0:


- $25=\dfrac{1}{2}(a{)(5)}^2$
- $a=2$ m s$^{-2}$

By applying Newton’s Second Law to the object,
$\begin{aligned}
F&=ma\\
\hspace{1.5em}16-12&=(m)(2)\\
m&=2\textrm{ kg}\\
\end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 99
list.content: - Define Newton's First Law. [2] - A block of mass 2.0 kg slides at the constant speed of $v$ on a rough inclined plane. A string attached to the hanging mass of 0.50 kg passes over a pulley and supports the block. The slope of the incline is 25$\degree$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/67a19126-12d9-4478-afd2-f45c35ba5e95/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.46.01%E2%80%AFAM.png) $\small{\textrm{[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$ - Show that the direction of the motion of the box is down the slope. [3] - Draw and label a free-body diagram for the forces acting on the block. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/d218363b-c52d-447a-a681-c5888a85a386/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.48.51%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Determine the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the inclined plane. [3] - In reality, air resistance will also have an effect on the motion of the block and the calculated coefficient of friction. If air resistance were taken into account for this constant speed scenario, discuss how the calculated value would be affected. [2]
list.markScheme:
- When the net force acting on the body is zero $\checkmark$
  The body has constant velocity/does not accelerate $\checkmark$
  $\textbf{OR}$
  An object at constant velocity $\ll$and in a state of rest$\gg$ will remain so $\checkmark$
  Unless acted on by an external/unbalanced force $\checkmark$



- 
  - Tension/Weight of the mass hunger = $\ll (0.50)(9.81) = \gg$ $4.9$ N $\checkmark$
    The component of the weight of the block on the plane of incline = $\ll (2.0)(9.81)(sin25) = \gg(2.0)(9.81)(0.42)$ = $8.3$ N $\checkmark$
    8.3 > 4.9 $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The direction of the friction on the block should be in the opposite direction of the block's motion.
    There is no acceleration. According to Newton's second law, there is no net force either on the object separately or the system. The forces on the block must be balanced.
    Weight $W_T$ of the block:
    
    
    - $W_T = mg = (2.0)(9.81) = 20$ N

    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Tx}$ on the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Tx} = mg\sin25\degree = (19.62)(0.42) = 8.3$ N

    Weight $W_M$ of the mass hanger:
    
    
    - $W_M = mg = (0.50)(9.81) = 4.9$ N

    The weight of the mass hanger should be the tension of the string and the tension of the spring is less than the component of the weight of the block. Therefore, the friction force acting on the block should be up to the slope. The block moves down to the slope.
    
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/13bfe0ba-398f-410a-8572-e2e8f45b8c5e/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.54.23%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    Correct directions and labels $\checkmark$
    Weight is longer than the other three by eye $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Four forces are acting on the block. They are weight towards the bottom of the page, normal force perpendicular to the plane of incline, tension and frictional force up to the slope. Since weight balances the vertical components of the other three forces, it should be greater in magnitude. This can be represented by longer arrows in the free-body diagram.
    
  - Normal reaction force = $\ll$ Component of the weight perpendicular to the plane of incline $=\gg 18$ N $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $8.3\textrm{ N} - 4.9\textrm{ N} = 3.4\textrm{ N}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\mu_d = \dfrac{3.4}{18}$ = 0.19 $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The net force acting on the block should be zero. The forces on the plane of incline are the force of dynamic friction, the tension up to the slope and the component of weight down to the slope. The force of dynamic friction $F_f$:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu_dF_N$

    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Tx}$ on the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Tx} = mg\sin25° = (2.0)(9.81)(0.42) = 8.3$ N

    The tension $T$:
    
    
    - $T = W_m = mg = (0.50)(9.81) = 4.9$ N

    The forces that are perpendicular to the plane of the incline are normal reaction force and the component of the weight of the block.
    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Ty}$ perpendicular to the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Ty} = mg\cos25° = (2.0)(9.81)(0.91) = 18$ N

    $W_{Ty}$ must be equal to $R$.
    So, dynamic friction can be rewritten as:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu_dW_{Ty}$

    Since $W_{Tx}$ must be balanced with $F_f$ and $T$:
    
    
    - $F_f+T=W_{Tx}$
    - $\mu_d W_{Ty}=W_{Tx}-T$
    - $\mu_d = \dfrac{W_{Tx}-T}{W_{Ty}} = \dfrac{8.3-4.9}{18} = 0.19$

    
  - air resistance also contributes a force up the slope, which means there is less force due to dynamic friction. $\checkmark$
    the calculated value for the coefficient of friction would be lower $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The direction of air resistance is always opposite to the motion of the object. Therefore, it is in the same direction as the force of dynamic friction and tension. Instead of the force of dynamic friction with tension only, the resultant force of air friction, tension and the force of dynamic friction balances the component of weight. Hence, the force of dynamic friction would be lower. This would lead to a lower calculated value for coefficient of friction.

list.title: Question 100
list.content:
A person pulls a rope with a force $F$ at an angle of $60\degree$ to the horizontal. The rope is connected to a load over a frictionless pulley as shown in the diagram below. The load is stationary.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/ea5d85f8-2a4b-407d-bde2-c01902d8451b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.20.21%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Which of the following is correct about the weight of the load and the net force exerted on the pulley by the rope?

$\hspace{1.5em}$Weight of the load$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$Net force exerted on the pulley by the rope$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $F$Less than  2$F$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $F$Equal to 2$F$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Equal to $F$Less than  2$F$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Equal to $F$Equal to 2$F$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The tension in the rope is $F$. Therefore, the box experiences an upward force of $F$. The downward force acting on the box is its weight. The box is travelling at a constant speed - Newton's first law tells us that the net force must be zero. Therefore: weight $= F$.
The rope exerted a force $F$ downwards and a force $F$ at angle $60\degree$ below the horizontal on the pulley. This is illustrated below
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/6b2ae24d-3208-4882-a9ef-53e12033d495/image.png)


The vector sum of these forces is the total force exerted by the rope on the pulley. This is illustrated below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd832937-5a94-4ec9-939b-66a7314f23be/images/e1534455-65cc-48b2-83e0-f7906e3e0e1f/image.png)


This vector sum must be less than 2$F$. The greatest possible vector sum of two vectors magnitude $F$ will be when they are pointing in the same direction.

list.title: Question 101
list.content: A washing machine contains a cylinder that carries clothes and rotates in a circular motion about a horizontal axis as shown in the diagram. Frictional forces act between the clothes and the inner surface of the cylinder. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/7a7a1a0e-4360-43f7-bff1-e494115729c8/PH0641.png) The radius of the cylinder is $0.27$ m and its linear speed of rotation of the outside of the cylinder is $1.60$ m s$^{-1}$. - Draw the free body diagram for the piece of clothing at the position shown. [3] - - The laundry machine cylinder is designed to make the piece of clothing lose contact with the cylinder at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal as shown. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/a3196421-cf22-4499-a5ba-d1c29429d5da/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.12.44%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) The free body diagram for the piece of clothing at this position is given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/b1c0dad4-0f88-4747-b2da-170b6286eea4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.13.51%E2%80%AFAM.png) Give an expression for the centripetal force at the position shown. [1] - Calculate the angular speed, expressing your answer to the correct number of significant figures. [3] - Show that $\theta=75\degree$ when the piece of clothing loses contact with the cylinder. [2] - Determine the time taken for a piece of clothing to move from the lowest point of the cylinder (point A) to the point where it loses contact. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/e607d6fc-b5eb-4a30-8f11-d0eb837b7b2b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.14.34%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
- $\hspace{1em}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/b10324d1-96ec-4217-a8aa-81a044ec36b4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.11.09%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


  Gravitational force vertically downwards. $\checkmark$
Friction force vertically upwards. $\checkmark$
Normal force horizontally to the right. $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - 
    
    - $N + mg \sin\theta$ $\checkmark$

    
  - 
    
    - $\omega=\ll\dfrac{v}{r}=\gg\dfrac{1.60}{0.27}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\omega$ = $5.9\ll\ rad\,s^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

    2 significant figures $\checkmark$
    
  - Normal force is zero $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\sin\theta$ $\checkmark$
    - $\sin\theta=\ll\dfrac{v^2}{rg}\ = \gg\dfrac{{(1.6)}^2}{(0.27)(9.81)}$  $\checkmark$
    - $\theta={\ll75}\degree\gg$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When the piece of clothing loses contact, the normal force of the cylinder on the clothing is zero.
    The centripetal force in this case is only the component of the gravitational force towards the centre of the circular path.
    
    
    - $mg\sin\theta\ =\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$

    Then,
    
    
    - $\sin\ \theta=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}\ =\dfrac{\left(1.6\right)^2}{\left(0.27\right)\left(9.81\right)}\ =0.967$
    - $\theta  ={75}\degree$

    
  - The angular displacement is 2.9 rad $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $t=\ll\dfrac{\theta}{\omega}\gg=\dfrac{2.9}{5.9}$ $\checkmark$
    - $t$ =$0.49\ll$ s $\gg$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Angular displacement is 90$\degree$ + 75$\degree$  = 165$\degree$
    In radians, this gives
    
    
    - $\dfrac{\left(165\right)\left(\pi\right)}{180}=2.9$ rad
    - $t=\dfrac{\theta}{\omega}=\dfrac{2.9}{5.9} $

    Allow ECF for use of $\omega$ value from b(ii)

list.title: Question 102
list.content:
A rocket is moving in the absence of a gravitational field with constant speed. It starts to accelerate by burning fuel. At the start, the fuel contributes to most of the mass of the rocket. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of $v$  relative to the rocket and a constant rate of $\sigma\ {kg\,s}^{-1}$. Which graph shows the variation of acceleration $a$ of the rocket with time $t$ as most of the fuel is used?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/d73b21e2-e1fb-4bf9-92cf-9ac8121ccc18/PH0583a.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/abf76f2f-87c3-412a-a029-1b61180b8190/PH0583b.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/8216d464-f854-405c-85a8-1ea9ebe0d6df/PH0583c.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e7060cb9-df03-455a-9ad3-9ae05af73650/images/926c08c6-953b-475d-a760-ecf65928e706/PH0583d.png)
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The resultant force $F_{net}$ acting on the space rocket:


- $F_{net}=ma \hspace{2em}$

Where $m$ is the mass of the rocket at any given time.
When fuel is ejected from the rocket, it experiences a change in momentum in the frame of reference of the rocket.
A given mass $m$ of fuel has its velocity change from 0 relative to the rocket to its ejected speed of $v$.
Therefore the change of momentum of this mass of fuel is $p_2 - p_1 = mv - 0 = mv$
The force on the fuel causing this change in momentum is given by the equation
$\hspace{2em}F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{mv}{\Delta t}$
And we know that the rate of fuel ejected is
$\sigma$ which equal to $\dfrac{m}{\Delta t}$
Therefore the net force on the ejected fuel is


- $F_{net}=v\sigma$

Therefore


- $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{M}=\dfrac{v\sigma}{M}$

where $M$ is the total initial mass of the rocket and $v$ is the velocity of the ejected fuel relative to the rocket.
The mass $m_f$ of the burned fuel after the time $t$:


- $m_f=\sigma t$

The total mass of the rocket decreases over time due to burned fuel ejection, the acceleration of the rocket after the time $t$:


- $a=\dfrac{v\sigma}{\left(M-\sigma t\right)}$

According to this relationship, acceleration increases at an increasing rate. So the answer is D.
Qualitatively, the total mass of the rocket is constantly decreasing due to the ejected fuel. As the fuel is ejected at a constant rate, there is a constant net force on the rocket. With a constant net force and decreasing mass, there will be an increasing acceleration. At the start, the change in mass will have little effect on the acceleration, but over time the effect of the decrease in mass will become more and more significant and result in greater and greater acceleration.

list.title: Question 103
list.content:
A jet of water with a cross sectional area of $A$ strikes perpendicular to a wall at a speed of $v$. After the collision, the water loses all of its horizontal speed and falls to the ground. The magnitude of the force created on the wall due to the water is $F$.
Which expression give the density of the water?



- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av^2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{F}{Av}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} 	FAv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	FAv^2$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Considering the mass of water that strikes the wall in 1 second:


- $m=\rho V \hspace{2em}$

where $\rho$ is the density of the water and $V$ is the volume of the water.
Assigning the length of the column of water to be $l$ and cross sectional area $A$


- $m=\rho V=\rho Al$

But $l = vt$ and $t=1$, therefore $l\ =v$
Giving


- $m=\rho Av$

After the impact, the horizontal velocity of the jet is zero.


- $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\hspace{2em}$ and   $\hspace{2em}\Delta t = 1$
- $F=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{1}=m\Delta v$
$ = (\rho Av)v\ =\ \rho Av^2$

Rearranging gives


- $\rho=\dfrac{F}{Av^2}$

list.title: Question 104
list.content:
A box of mass $3$ kg is placed on a box of mass $7$ kg. The coefficient of static friction between the surfaces of the boxes is 0.5. A horizontal force $F$ is applied to the $7$ kg box which sits on a frictionless surface.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/452f270b-6451-4959-b170-f51f3cf61e4b/PH0549.png)


What is the maximum value of $F$ that can move the boxes without the $3$ kg box slipping?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$  1 N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$  5 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$  10 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$  50 N
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The free-body diagrams of the boxes:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/19ee0e9b-367f-408b-871c-526728275c32/images/9d860ecd-59e5-4504-b19f-2b1efaf7504f/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.51.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Note that it is friction from the bottom box that provides the net force that accelerates the $3$ kg box, and this same force of friction pulls backwards on the $7$ kg box.
The maximum value of the force of friction $F_f$ can be calculated as follows;


- $F_f=\mu_s F_N=\mu_s mg=(0.5)(3)g=1.5g = 15$ N

When Newton's Second Law is applied to the mass of $3$ kg;


- $F_{net}=ma$
- $1.5g=3a$
- $0.5g=a$

To move without slipping, both of the masses must have the same acceleration. Treating both boxes as one system


- $F_{net}=ma$
- $F_{net}=(10)(0.5g)$
- $F=5(10)=50$ N

Hence, the correct answer is D.

list.title: Question 105
list.content:
Two objects of masses $m$ and $M$ collide and stick together. Both objects have the same initial speed and follow paths illustrated below. The line on the diagram shows the line of symmetry between the paths of the two objects before the collision.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/ec016aeb-9f8f-41a8-b4b3-e167e4537ee0/image.png)


After the collision the combined mass moves away from the origin making an angle $\theta$ above the original line of symmetry.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/5f938649-a4ed-49cc-83d0-4bec94b329c9/image.png)


What is $\tan{\theta}$?



- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}{M+m}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{(M-m)}{(M+m)\tan{\alpha}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{(M+m)\tan{\alpha}}{M-m}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{(M+m)}{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Let $v$ be the speed of the objects before the collision and $x$ and $y$ refer to the horizontal and vertical directions respectively.
We can resolve for $x$ and $y$ components of velocity. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/a12b58e6-4ea7-4a8a-a264-fc6269dc5123/image.png)


Using the diagram above
Total $y$ momentum $= Mv\sin{\alpha}-mv\sin{\alpha}=(M-m)v\sin{\alpha}$
($y$ velocity of $m$ is negative as it points in the negative $y$ direction)
Total $x$ momentum $= Mv\cos{\alpha}+mv\cos{\alpha}=(M+m)v\cos{\alpha}$
Both total $x$ and $y$ momenta will be unchanged after collision. So
$y$ momentum of combined mass $= (M-m)v\sin{\alpha}$
$x$ momentum of combined mass $= (M+m)v\cos{\alpha}$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95e0fa46-1e0d-4c6b-bb3b-6ffc9dc7850e/images/fe66386b-9c31-4c76-9d6e-6fc8ab26a704/image.png)




- $\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}=\dfrac{(M-m)v\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)v\cos{\alpha}}=\dfrac{(M-m)\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)\cos{\alpha}}$

Also


- $\dfrac{\sin{\alpha}}{\cos{\alpha}}=\tan{\alpha}$

Therefore


- $\tan{\theta}=\dfrac{(M-m)\sin{\alpha}}{(M+m)\cos{\alpha}}= \dfrac{(M-m)\tan{\alpha}}{(M+m)}$

list.title: Question 106
list.content:
A stationary observer sees a spacecraft of initial total mass $M$ that is moving through a vacuum at a speed $v$. A satellite of mass $m$ is released with a velocity $u$ sideways relative to the spacecraft with use of a force that acts perpendicular to the side of the spacecraft. What is the final speed of the spacecraft relative to the stationary observer?
Assume speeds are not relativistic.



- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\sqrt{v^2+u^2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\sqrt{\Bigl(\dfrac{Mv}{M-m}\Bigr)^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\sqrt{\Bigl(\dfrac{mv}{M-m}\Bigr)^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Let $v$ point in the positive $x$ direction and $u$ point in the positive $y$ direction (as this is a convenient choice of coordinates to work with).
Below is a diagram showing the $x$ and $y$ velocities of the object and the spacecraft after they are separated.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/95f40ff2-d6ca-4ac6-ab32-a5f8ccd9bec4/images/f0790782-dc71-4390-b303-ac36a13a2d64/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.27.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)


$\textbf{Conservation of momentum in the}\,x\,\textbf{direction}$
$x$ velocity of object and spacecraft after release is $v$ - we know this because the object is released perpendicular to $v$ (total $x$ momentum is unchanged).
$\textbf{Conservation of momentum in the}\,y\,\textbf{direction}$
The mass of the spacecraft after the object is released is $M-m$


- $0=(M-m)(y\,\text{velocity of spacecraft})+mu$
- $y\,\text{velocity of spacecraft}= -\dfrac{mu}{M-m}$ (minus sign because this velocity points in the opposite direction to $u$)

Using Pythagoras to find speed (magnitude of velocity)


- speed $= \sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(-\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}=\sqrt{v^2+\Bigl(\dfrac{mu}{M-m}\Bigr)^2}$

list.title: Question 107
list.content: - State Newton's Third Law. [2] - A block of mass 2.0 kg is placed on another block of mass 5.0 kg. The blocks sit on a frictionless surface, but the coefficient of static friction between the blocks is 0.50. The block at the top is pulled with a varying horizontal force $F$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/be6d5caa-15a5-4319-bcbe-83970ed4e5e3/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.12.55%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Calculate the magnitude of the maximum force $F_{max}$ which results in both of the blocks moving together without slipping. [3] - On the graph, sketch how the force of static friction $F_f$ acting on the bottom block varies with the force $F$. [2] (no need to add values on the axis) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/8cdd5549-4070-486e-8593-4ad4bbed35bd/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.06.47%E2%80%AFPM.png) $F_{max}$ is your answer to (b)(i) and draw your graph up to $F_{max}$ - According to Newton's Third Law, there must be another force paired with the weight of the top block. Describe this force. [2] - On another occasion, the blocks are moved with the help of a force of $12$ N acting on the block at the top. The drag force $D$ on the blocks is given by $D=0.025v^2$ where $v$ is the speed of the blocks. Calculate the top speed of the blocks for this force. [2]
list.markScheme:
- when two bodies A and B interact, the $\ll$action$\gg$ $\underline{\textrm{force}}$ that A exerts on B is equal and $\checkmark$
  opposite in direction to the $\ll$reaction$\gg$ $\underline{\textrm{force}}$ that B exerts on A $\checkmark$



- 
  - The magnitude of maximum force of friction = $ \mu_s R =  9.8$ N $\checkmark$
    The acceleration of both blocks = $\ll \dfrac{F_{fmax}}{5} = \gg = 1.96 =2.0$ m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$
    $ F = ma  = \ll(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=\gg$ 14 N  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To have the blocks moving together, the acceleration of each block must be the same. The vertical forces on each block cancel each other. Therefore, only horizontal forces create acceleration. The only horizontal force acting on the block with a mass of 5.0 kg is the force due to static friction between the blocks. The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law ($F_{net}=ma$):
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/3af533e6-d79a-41ea-8adb-f805fc93cde4/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law ($F_{net}=ma$):
    
    
    - $F_f = 5a \hspace{2em}$ (first expression)

    Two horizontal forces are acting on the 2.0 kg mass as $F$ and the force of static friction.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/4c19e1d9-65aa-4a50-a913-d1ad7c2cc1f6/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    The acceleration of 2.0 kg mass can be found by:
    
    
    - $F - F_f = 2.0a \hspace{2em}$ (second expression)

    Since maximum $F$ is investigated, the maximum value of $F_f$ should be employed.
    
    
    - $F_{fmax}=\mu_s R \hspace{1em}$    where $\mu_s=0.5$ and $R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20$ N
    - $F_{fmax} = (0.50)(20) = 9.8$ N

    This is the net force acting on the bottom block. We can use this to find the acceleration. When $F_{fmax}$ is substituted to the first expression:
    
    
    - $9.8 = 5.0a$
    - $1.96$ m s$^{-2}=a$

    As both blocks must have the same acceleration, they can be treated as one object of mass $2 + 5  = 7$ kg
    The applied force F is also the net force for the two blocks
    Therefore,
    
    
    - $F_{net} = ma = (7)(1.96) = 13.7 =14$ N


  
  
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/bf06ade7-18bc-4506-ab6a-19bdab0c0710/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.08.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    a straight line $\checkmark$
    passing through the origin $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When both of the objects are considered as one block. There is no opposing force due to a lack of friction between the surface and bottom block. Hence, the applied force can not be balanced and the acceleration of the blocks will never be zero. The forces acting on the block at the top are the force of static friction $F_f$  (It is the same as the friction force on the block at the bottom) and applied force F. The net force on the top block:
    
    
    - $F - F_f = 2a \hspace{2em} a \neq 0$

    Due to this relationship, when $F$ is increased, $F_f$ is also increased. The maximum value for the force of static friction:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu N = (0.5)(2.0)(9.81) = 9.8\textrm{ N}$ when the $F_{max}$ is applied.

    Since there is no scaling on the x and y axis, this relation can be expressed with a straight line passing through the origin at any angle.
    
  - The gravitational pull of  mass at the top $\checkmark$
    on the earth $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The paired force should be on the other object and the same type of force. Since weight is the pull of the earth on the mass, paired force should be the pull of the mass on the earth.
    

- $\hspace{2.2em} F = Dv^2$
  
  
  - $12 = 0.025v^{-2} \checkmark$
  - $v = \ll \sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = \gg$ 22 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The acceleration of the blocks must be zero when they are moving at top speed. The resultant force should be zero to have no acceleration. Since two forces acting on the blocks are drag force and 12 N, they must be balanced by each other;
  
  
  - $F = D v^2$
  - $12=(2.5 \times 10^{-2})(v^2)$
  - $\dfrac{12}{0.025} = v^2$
  - $\sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = v$
  - $v = 22$ m s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 108
list.content:
An object of mass $1.0$ kg rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass $2.0$ kg is connected to it with a string.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/5ad23e85-206e-4711-b2ed-20c0481d45a3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.53.49%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When the objects are released, the masses accelerate at $\dfrac{g}{2}$. The work done by the tension of the string on the $1.0$ kg mass is $40$ J. Which of the following is correct for the $1.0$ kg mass during this period?

Magnitude of the force of friction / NDistance travelled / m$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$2.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$2.0$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The acceleration is given as $\dfrac{g}{2}$ which is equal to $\dfrac{10}{2} = 5$ m s$^{-2}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $2.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/c2d6f4fb-acd4-4d56-a0c4-8def2c43d211/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


According to Newton's second law, the relationship between tension $T$, the weight of the object $W$ and the acceleration of the object:
$\begin{aligned}
F_{net}&=ma\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
W_2-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
(2)(10)-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T&=10\textrm{ N}\\
\end{aligned}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $1.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/60248a9f-84bf-4dfd-b06e-48f3db63eec5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.51%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The normal reaction force $F_N$ of the ground on the box balances the weight $W$ of the object. According to Newton's second law, the relationship between Tension $T$, the force of friction on the object $F_f$ and the acceleration of the object


- $T-F_f=(1.0)(5)$

When the magnitude of $T$ is substituted in the equation;


- $10-F_f=(1.0)(5)$
- $\hspace{2em}F_f=5$ N

The work done $W$ by $T$ can be found by the product of $T$ and the distance $d$ travelled by the object.


- $W_1=Td$
- $40=10d$
- $d=4.0$ m

list.title: Question 109
list.content:
An object is swung at the end of a rigid rod in a vertical circle at a constant speed $v$ such that there is an outward tension on the rod at all times. The radius of the circle is $r$. This is illustrated in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/509a7eb6-1250-45e2-b3d2-4474aebbfe64/PH0946.png)


The tension in the rod when the object is at its lowest point in the circle is 50% greater than the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point.
Which of the following expressions is equivalent to the acceleration of freefall on Earth, $g$?



- A. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}$
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{2v{^2}}{3r}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{v{^2}}{r}$
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ $\dfrac{3v{^2}}{2r}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Below shows a free body diagram for the object at its highest and lowest points.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe75a6af-4f26-486a-a8a6-c3c7a1d1385d/images/cb338b09-6560-4e28-87e1-f9046c093a52/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.54.38%E2%80%AFAM.png)


In both scenarios the object is moving in a circle therefore the net force is a centripetal force. Beccause the speed and radius are constant, the centrepetal acceleration is the same at both locations.


- $F_{net}=ma = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Where $m$ is the mass of the object.
(Acceleration is always towards the centre of the circle so at highest point acceleration points downwards and at highest point acceleration points upwards)
Let the tension in the rod when the object is at its highest point be $T$. We are told that the tension at the lowest point is 50% higher, therefore at the lowest point the tension is $1.5T$.
Highest point:


- $T + mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Lowest point:


- $1.5T - mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$

Now solving these to eliminate $T$:


- $3T + 3mg = \dfrac{3mv{^2}}{r}$



- $3T - 2mg = \dfrac{2mv{^2}}{r}$

Subtracting the equations gives


- $5mg = \dfrac{mv{^2}}{r}$



- $g = \dfrac{v{^2}}{5r}$

list.title: Question 110
list.content:
A piece of metal of weight $W$ is suspended by two identical strings. Each string passes through a pulley and is attached to a block of mass $m$. The system is in equilibrium
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d519955-6a40-4506-8274-69c20c98f6a3/images/81305a51-e6a0-44a0-be2b-bb613ea8d76b/Sc%CF%88reenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.06.05%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
What must be true for $m$ such that the two strings attached to the piece of metal are almost horizontal?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $m < \dfrac{W}{g}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{W}{2g} < m < \dfrac{W}{g}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $m > \dfrac{W}{g}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $m < \dfrac{W}{2g}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For a string to be almost horizontal, the angle of inclination of the string $\theta$ will be very small
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d519955-6a40-4506-8274-69c20c98f6a3/images/034ebe4c-40fd-44b9-b867-12650cee1d1d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.05.05%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
The piece of metal is stationary, so $W=2T\sin\theta$
For very small inclination angle $\theta$, $\sin\theta$ will be very small
For the above equation to be valid; the value of the tension T in the string must be very high. T >> W
$T = mg$
Which means that the mass of the block must be higher than the mass of the metal. So $m > \frac{W}{g}$

list.title: Question 111
list.content:
A ball of mass $0.4$ kg is attached to a string of length $0.2$ m and is moving in a vertical circular path with tangential speed of $\sqrt3$ m s$^{-1}$ at the instant shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/ad595940-00d7-4646-b95f-3a474d1c2590/PH0635.png)



Given that $\sin(60\degree)=\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}$ and $\cos(60\degree)=\dfrac{1}{2}$, what is the tension in the string at the shown position?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $(6+2\sqrt3)$ N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 8 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 4 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $(6-2\sqrt3)$ N
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The ball is rotating in a vertical circular path, then the forces acting on it is the tension of the string and the weight.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f5614af-5167-4bb5-9a52-95fd7da2e05a/images/f8dd71e5-0c6c-4fd6-ada2-f88ed05e3b06/PH0635a.png)


The centripetal force acting on the ball is the vector sum of the tension of the string and the component of the weight that is the same direction as the string
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_c=T-mg\cos(60\degree)$
The centripetal force
$\hspace{2em}$ $F_c=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$
Then
$\hspace{2em}$ $T=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mg\cos(60\degree)$
$\hspace{2em}$ $T=\dfrac{(0.4){(\sqrt3)}^2}{0.2}+\left(0.4\right)\left(10\right)\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)$
$\hspace{2.9em}$ = $8$ N
